verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:1
verses.text: First Epistle of John Prologue: Ye remember, holy brethren, that the Gospel according to John, read in orderly course of lessons, is the subject on which we usually discourse: but because of the now intervening solemnity of the holy days, on which there must be certain lessons recited in the Church, which so come every year that they cannot be other than they are: the order which we had undertaken is of necessity for a little while intermitted, not wholly omitted.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:2
verses.text: But when I was thinking what matter of discourse upon the Scriptures, agreeable with the cheerfulness of these days, I might undertake with you, as the Lord shall vouchsafe to grant, during the present week, being such an one as might be finished in these seven or eight days; the Epistle of blessed John occurred to me: that whereas we have for a while intermitted the reading of his Gospel, we may in discoursing upon his Epistle not go from his side: the rather, as in this same Epistle, which is very sweet to all who have a healthy taste of the heart to relish the Bread of God, and very meet to be had in remembrance in God's Holy Church, charity is above all commended.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:3
verses.text: He has spoken many words, and nearly all are about charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:4
verses.text: He that hath in himself that which he is to hear, must needs rejoice at that which he heareth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:5
verses.text: For so shall this reading be to that man, as oil upon flame; if that be there which may be nourished, it is nourished and groweth and abideth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:6
verses.text: Again, to some it ought to be as flame to fuel; that if he did not burn, by added discourse he may be  set on fire.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:7
verses.text: For in some that which is there, is nourished: in some it is kindled, if it be not there: that we all may rejoice in one charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:8
verses.text: But where charity, there peace; and where humility, there charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 1:9
verses.text: Now let us hear himself: and at his words, what the Lord suggests, that let us speak also to you, that ye may well understand.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1
verses.text: Homily I.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2
verses.text: 1 John I.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:3
verses.text: 1â€“II.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:4
verses.text: 11  "That which was from the beginning, which we have heard, and which we have seen with our eyes, and our hands have handled, of the Word of life: and the life was manifested, and we have seen, and bear witness, and show unto you that eternal life, which was with the Father, and was manifested unto us: the things which we have seen and heard declare we unto you, that ye also may have fellowship with us: and that our fellowship may be  with the Father, and with His Son Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:5
verses.text: And these things write we unto you, that your joy may be full.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:6
verses.text: This then is the message which we have heard of Him, and declare unto you, that God is light, and in Him is no darkness at all.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:7
verses.text: If we say that we have fellowship with Him, and walk in darkness, we lie, and do not the truth: if we walk in the light, as He is in the light, we have fellowship one with another, and the blood of Jesus Christ His Son shall cleanse  us from all sin.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:8
verses.text: If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:9
verses.text: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:10
verses.text: If we say that we have not sinned, we make Him a liar, and His word is not in us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:11
verses.text: My little children, these things write I unto you, that ye sin not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:12
verses.text: And if any man sin, we have an Advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous: and He is the propitiation for our sins: not for our's only, but also for the sins of the whole world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:13
verses.text: And in this we do know Him, if we keep His commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:14
verses.text: He that saith he knoweth Him, and keepeth not His commandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:15
verses.text: But whoso keepeth His word, in him verily is the love of God perfected.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:16
verses.text: In this we know that we are in Him, if in Him we be perfect.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:17
verses.text: He that saith he abideth in Him ought himself also so to walk, even as He walked.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:18
verses.text: Beloved, I write no new commandment unto you, but an old commandment which ye had from the beginning.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:19
verses.text: The old commandment is the word which ye have heard.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:20
verses.text: Again, a new commandment I write unto you, which thing is true in Him and in you: because the darkness is past, and the true light now shineth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:21
verses.text: He that saith he is in the light, and hateth his brother, is in darkness even until now.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:22
verses.text: He that loveth his brother abideth in the light, and there is none occasion of stumbling in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:23
verses.text: For he that hateth his brother is in darkness, and walketh in darkness, and knoweth not whither he goeth, because the darkness hath blinded his eyes".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:25
verses.text: "That which was from the beginning, which we have heard, which we have seen with our eyes, and our hands have handled, of the word of life".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:26
verses.text: Who is he that with hands doth handle the Word, except because "The Word was made flesh, and dwelt in us"? Now this Word which was made flesh that it might be handled, began to be flesh, of the Virgin Mary: but not then began the Word, for the Apostle saith, "That which was from the beginning".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:27
verses.text: See whether his epistle does not bear witness to his gospel, where ye lately heard, "In the beginning was  the Word, and the Word was with God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:28
verses.text: Perchance, "Concerning the word of life" one may take as a sort of expression concerning Christ, not the very body of Christ which was handled with hands.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:29
verses.text: See what follows: "And the Life was manifested".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:30
verses.text: Christ therefore is "the word of life".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:31
verses.text: And whereby manifested? For it was "from the beginning," only not manifested to men: but it was manifested to angels, who saw it and fed on it as their bread.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:32
verses.text: But what saith the Scripture? "Man did eat angels' bread".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:33
verses.text: Well then "the Life was manifested" in the flesh; because it exhibited in manifestation, that that which can be seen by the heart only, should be seen by the eyes also, that it might heal the hearts.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:34
verses.text: For only by the heart is the Word seen: but the flesh is seen by the bodily eyes also.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:35
verses.text: We had wherewith to see the flesh, but had not wherewith to see the Word: "the Word was made flesh," which we might see, that so that in us might be healed wherewith we might see the Word.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:37
verses.text: "And we have seen and are witnesses".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:38
verses.text: Perhaps some of the brethren who are not acquainted with the Greek do not know what the word "witnesses" is in Greek: and yet it is a term much used by all, and had in religious reverence; for what in our tongue we call "witnesses," in Greek are "martyrs".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:39
verses.text: Now where is the man that has not heard of martyrs, or where the Christian in whose mouth the name of martyrs dwelleth not every day and would that it so dwelt in the heart also, that we should imitate the sufferings of the martyrs, not persecute them with our cups! Well then, "We have seen and are witnesses," is as much as to say, We have seen and are martyrs.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:40
verses.text: For it was for bearing witness of that which they had seen, and bearing witness of that which they had heard from them who had seen, that, while their testimony itself displeased the men against whom it was delivered, the martyrs suffered all that they did suffer.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:41
verses.text: The martyrs are God's witnesses.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:42
verses.text: It pleased God to have men for His witnesses, that men also may have God to be their witness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:43
verses.text: "We have seen," saith he, "and are witnesses".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:44
verses.text: Where have they seen? In the manifestation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:45
verses.text: What meaneth, in the manifestation? In the sun, that is, in this light of day.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:46
verses.text: And how should He be seen in the sun who made the sun, except as "in the sun He hath set His tabernacle; and Himself as a bridegroom going forth out of his chamber, exulted as a giant to run His course?" He before the sun, who made the sun, He before the day-star, before all the stars, before all angels, the true Creator, ("for all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made,") that He might be seen by eyes of flesh which see the sun, set His very tabernacle in the sun, that is, showed His flesh in manifestation of this light of day: and that Bridegroom's chamber was the Virgin's womb, because in that virginal womb were joined the two, the Bridegroom and the bride, the Bridegroom the Word, and the bride the flesh; because it is written, "And they twain shall be one flesh;" and the Lord saith in the Gospel, "Therefore they are no more twain but one flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:47
verses.text: And Esaias remembers right well that they are two: for speaking in the person of Christ he saith, "He hath set a mitre upon me as upon a bridegroom, and adorned me with an ornament as a bride".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:48
verses.text: One seems to speak, yet makes Himself at once Bridegroom and Bride; because "not two, but one flesh:" because "the Word was made flesh, and dwelt in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:49
verses.text: To that flesh the Church is joined, and so there is made the whole Christ, Head and body.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:51
verses.text: "And we are witnesses, and show unto you that eternal life, which was with the Father, and was manifested unto us:" i-e:, manifested among us: which might be more plainly expressed, manifested to us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:52
verses.text: "The things," therefore, "which we have seen and heard, declare we unto you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:53
verses.text: Those saw the Lord Himself present in the flesh, and heard words from the mouth of the Lord, and told them to us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:54
verses.text: Consequently we also have heard, but have not seen.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:55
verses.text: Are we then less happy than those who saw and heard? And how does he add, "That ye also may have fellowship with us"? Those saw, we have not seen, and yet we are fellows; because we hold the faith in common.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:56
verses.text: For there was one who did not believe even upon seeing, and would needs handle, and so believe, and said, "I will not believe except I thrust my fingers into the place of the nails, and touch His scars".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:57
verses.text: And He did give Himself for a time to be handled by the hands of men, who always giveth Himself to be seen by the sight of the angels; and that disciple did handle, and exclaimed, "My Lord, and my  God!" Because he touched the Man, he confessed the God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:58
verses.text: And the Lord, to console us who, now that He sitteth in heaven, cannot touch Him with the hand, but only reach Him with faith, said to him, "Because thou hast seen, thou hast believed; blessed are they that have not seen, and yet believe".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:59
verses.text: We are here described, we designated.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:60
verses.text: Then let the blessedness take place in us, of which the Lord predicted that it should take place; let us firmly hold that which we see not; because those tell us who have seen.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:61
verses.text: "That ye also," saith he, "may have fellowship with us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:62
verses.text: And what great matter is it to have fellowship with men? Do not despise it; see what he adds: "and our fellowship may be  with God the Father, and Jesus Christ His Son.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:63
verses.text: And these things," saith he, "we write unto you, that your joy may be full".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:64
verses.text: Full joy he means in that fellowship, in that charity, in that unity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:66
verses.text: "And this is the message which we have heard of Him, and declare unto you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:67
verses.text: What is this? Those same have seen, have handled with their hands, the Word of life: He "was from the beginning," and for a time was made visible and palpable, the Only-begotten Son of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:68
verses.text: For what thing did He come, or what new thing did He tell us? What was it His will to teach? Wherefore did He this which He did, that the Word should be made flesh, that "God over all things" should suffer indignities from men, that He should endure to be smitten upon the face by the hands which Himself had made? What would He teach? What would He show? What would He declare? Let us hear: for without the fruit of the precept the hearing of the story, how Christ was born, and how Christ suffered, is a mere pastime of the mind, not a strengthening of it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:69
verses.text: What great thing hearest thou? With what fruit thou hearest, see to that.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:70
verses.text: What would He teach? What declare? Hear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:71
verses.text: That "God is light," saith he, "and there is no darkness in Him at all".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:72
verses.text: Hitherto, he hath named indeed the light, but the words are dark: good is it for us that the very light which he hath named should enlighten our hearts, and we should see what he hath said.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:73
verses.text: This it is that we declare, that "God is light, and there is no darkness in Him at all".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:74
verses.text: Who would dare to say that there is darkness in God? Or what is the light? Or what darkness? Lest haply he speaks of such things as pertain to these eyes of ours.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:75
verses.text: "God is light".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:76
verses.text: Saith some man, "The sun also is light, and the moon also is light, and a candle is light".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:77
verses.text: It ought to be something far greater than these, far more excellent, and far more surpassing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:78
verses.text: How much God is distant from the creature, how much the Maker from the making, how much Wisdom from that which is made by Wisdom, far beyond all things must this light needs be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:79
verses.text: And haply we shall be near to it, if we get to know what this light is, and apply ourselves unto it, that by it we may be enlightened; because in ourselves we are darkness, and only when enlightened by it can we become light, and not be put to confusion by it, being put to confusion by ourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:80
verses.text: Who is he that is put to confusion by himself? He that knows himself to be a sinner.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:81
verses.text: Who is he that by it is not put to confusion? He who by it is enlightened.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:82
verses.text: What is it to be enlightened by it? He that now sees himself to be darkened by sins, and desires to be enlightened by it, draws near to it: whence the Psalm saith, "Draw near unto Him, and be ye enlightened; and your faces shall not be ashamed".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:83
verses.text: But thou shalt not be shamed by it, if, when it shall show thee to thyself that thou art foul, thine own foulness shall displease thee, that thou mayest perceive its beauty.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:84
verses.text: This it is that He would teach.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:86
verses.text: And may it be that we say this over-hastily? Let the apostle himself make this plain in what follows.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:87
verses.text: Remember what was said at the outset of our discourse, that the present epistle commendeth charity: "God is light," saith he, "and in Him is no dark  ness at all".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:88
verses.text: And what said he above? "That ye may have fellowship with us, and our fellowship may be with God the Father, and with His Son Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:89
verses.text: But moreover, if "God be light, and in Him is no darkness at all, and we must have fellowship with Him," then from us also must the darkness be driven away, that there may be light created in us, for darkness cannot have fellowship with light.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:90
verses.text: To this end, see what follows: "If we say that we have fellowship with Him, and walk in darkness, we lie".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:91
verses.text: Thou hast also the Apostle Paul saying, "Or what fellowship hath light with darkness?" Thou sayest thou hast fellowship with God, and thou walkest in darkness; "and God is light, and in Him is no darkness at all:" then how should there be fellowship between light and darkness? At this point therefore a man may say to himself, What shall I do? how shall I be light? I live in sins and iniquities.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:92
verses.text: There steals upon him, as it were, a desperation and sadness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:93
verses.text: There is no salvation save in the fellowship of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:94
verses.text: "God is light, and in Him is no darkness at all".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:95
verses.text: But sins are darkness, as the Apostle saith of the devil and his angels, that they are "rulers of this darkness".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:96
verses.text: He would not call them of darkness, save as rulers of sins, having lordship over the wicked.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:97
verses.text: Then what are we to do, my brethren? Fellowship with God must be had, other hope of life eternal is none; now "God is Light, and in Him is no darkness at all:" now iniquities are darkness; by iniquities we are pressed down, that we cannot have fellowship with God: what hope have we then? Did I not promise to speak something during these days, that shall cause gladness? Which if I make not good, this is sadness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:98
verses.text: "God is Light, and in Him is no darkness at all;" sins are darkness: what shall become of us? Let us hear, whether peradventure He will console, lift up, give hope, that we faint not by the way.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:99
verses.text: For we are running, and running to our own country; and if we despair of attaining, by that very despair we fail.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:100
verses.text: But He whose will it is that we attain, that He may keep us safe in our own land, feedeth us in the way.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:101
verses.text: Hear we then: "If we say that we have fellowship with Him and walk in darkness, we lie, and do not the truth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:102
verses.text: Let us not say that we have fellowship with Him, if we walk in darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:103
verses.text: "If we walk in the light, as He is in the light, we have fellowship one with another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:104
verses.text: Let us walk in the light, as He is in the light, that we may be able to have fellowship with Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:105
verses.text: And what are we to do about our sins? Hear what follows, "And the blood of Jesus Christ His Son shall purge us from all sin".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:106
verses.text: Great assurance hath God given! Well may we celebrate the Passover, wherein was shed the blood of the Lord, by which we are cleansed "from all sin!" Let us be assured: the "handwriting which was against us," the bond of our slavery, the devil held, but by the blood of Christ it is blotted out.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:107
verses.text: "The blood," saith he, "of His Son shall purge us from all sin".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:108
verses.text: What meaneth, "from all sin"? Mark: lo even now, in the name of Christ whom these here have now confessed, who are called infants, have all their sins been cleansed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:109
verses.text: They came in old, they went out new.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:110
verses.text: How, came in old, went out new? Old men they came in, infants they went out.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:111
verses.text: For the old life is old age with all its dotage, but the new life is the infancy of regeneration.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:112
verses.text: But what are we to do? The past sins are pardoned, not only to these but to us; and after the pardon and abolition of all sins, by living in this world in the midst of temptations, some haply have been contracted.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:113
verses.text: Therefore what he can, let man do; let him confess himself to be what he is, that he may be cured by Him who always is what He is: for He always was and is; we were not and are.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:115
verses.text: For see what He saith; "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:116
verses.text: Consequently, if thou hast confessed thyself a sinner, the truth is in thee: for the Truth itself is light.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:117
verses.text: Thy life hath not yet shone in perfect brightness, because there are sins in thee; but yet thou hast already begun to be enlightened, because there is in thee the confession of sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:118
verses.text: For see what follows: "If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to purge us from all iniquity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:119
verses.text: Not  only the past, but haply if we have contracted any from this life; because a man, so long as he bears the flesh, cannot but have some at any rate light sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:120
verses.text: But these which we call light, do not thou make light of.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:121
verses.text: If thou make light of them when thou weighest them, be afraid when thou countest them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:122
verses.text: Many light make one huge sin: many drops fill the river; many grains make the lump.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:123
verses.text: And what hope is there? Before all, confession: lest any think himself righteous, and, before the eyes of God who seeth that which is, man, that was not and is, lift up the neck.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:124
verses.text: Before all, then, confession; then, love: for of charity what is said? "Charity covereth a multitude of sins".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:125
verses.text: Now let us see whether he commendeth charity in regard of the sins which subsequently overtake us: because charity alone extinguisheth sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:126
verses.text: Pride extinguisheth charity: therefore humility strengtheneth charity; charity extinguisheth sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:127
verses.text: Humility goes along with confession, the humility by which we confess ourselves sinners: this is humility, not to say it with the tongue, as if only to avoid arrogancy, lest we should displease men if we should say that we are righteous.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:128
verses.text: This do the ungodly and insane: "I know indeed that I am righteous, but what shall I say before men? If I shall call myself righteous, who will bear it, who tolerate? let my righteousness be known unto God: I however will say that I am a sinner, but only that I may not be found odious for arrogancy".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:129
verses.text: Tell men what thou art, tell God what thou art.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:130
verses.text: Because if thou tell not God what thou art, God condemneth what He shall find in thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:131
verses.text: Wouldest thou not that He condemn thee? Condemn thou.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:132
verses.text: Wouldest thou that He forgive? do thou acknowledge, that thou mayest be able to say unto God, "Turn Thy face from my sins".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:133
verses.text: Say also to Him those words in the same Psalm, "For I acknowledge mine iniquity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:134
verses.text: "If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to purge us from all iniquity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:135
verses.text: If we say that we have not sinned, we make Him a liar, and His word is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:136
verses.text: If thou shalt say, I have not sinned, thou makest Him a liar, while thou wishest to make thyself true.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:137
verses.text: How is it possible that God should be a liar, and man true, when the Scripture saith the contrary, "Every man a liar, God alone true"? Consequently, God true through Himself, thou true through God; because through thyself, a liar.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:139
verses.text: And lest haply he should seem to have given impunity for sins, in that he said, "He is faithful and just to cleanse us from all iniquity;" and men henceforth should say to themselves, Let us sin, let us do securely what we will, Christ purgeth us, is faithful and just, purgeth us from all iniquity: He taketh from thee an evil security, and putteth in an useful fear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:140
verses.text: To thine own hurt thou wouldest be secure; thou must be solicitous.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:141
verses.text: For "He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins," provided thou always displease thyself, and be changing until thou be perfected.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:142
verses.text: Accordingly, what follows? "My little children, these things I write unto you, that ye sin not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:143
verses.text: But perchance sin overtakes us from our mortal life: what shall be done then? What? shall there be now despair? Hear: "And if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous: and He is the propitiator for our sins".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:144
verses.text: He then is the advocate; do thou thine endeavor not to sin: if from the infirmity of this life sin shall overtake thee, see to it straightway, straightway be displeased, straightway condemn it; and when thou hast condemned, thou shalt come assured unto the Judge.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:145
verses.text: There hast thou the advocate: fear not to lose thy cause in thy confession.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:146
verses.text: For if oft-times in this life a man commits his cause to an eloquent tongue, and is not lost; thou committest thyself to the Word, and shalt thou be lost? Cry, "We have an advocate with the Father".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:148
verses.text: See John himself observing humility.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:149
verses.text: Assuredly he was a righteous and a great man, who from the Lord's bosom drank in the secrets of His mysteries; he, the man who by drinking from the Lord's bosom indited of His Godhead, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God:" he, being such a man as this, saith not, Ye have an advocate with the Father; but, "If any man sin, an advocate," saith he, "have we".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:150
verses.text: He saith not, ye have; nor saith, ye have me; nor saith, ye have Christ Himself: but he puts Christ, not himself, and saith, also, "We have," not, ye have.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:151
verses.text: He chose rather to put himself in the number of sinners that he might have Christ for his advocate, than to put himself in Christ's stead as advocate, and to be found among the proud that shall be condemned.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:152
verses.text: Brethren, Jesus Christ the righteous, even Him have we for our advocate with the Father; "He," even He, "is the propitiation for our sins".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:153
verses.text: This whoso hath held fast, hath made no heresy; this whoso hath held fast, hath made no schism.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:154
verses.text: For whence came schisms? When men say, "we" are righteous, when men say, "we" sanctify the unclean, "we"  justify the ungodly; "we" ask, "we" obtain.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:155
verses.text: But what saith John? "And if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:156
verses.text: But some man will say: then do the saints not ask for us? Then do bishops and rulers not ask for the people? Yea, but mark the Scriptures, and see that rulers also commend themselves to the prayers of the people.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:157
verses.text: Thus the apostle saith to the congregation, "Praying withal for us also".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:158
verses.text: The apostle prayeth for the people, the people prayeth for the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:159
verses.text: We pray for you, brethren: but do ye also pray for us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:160
verses.text: Let all the members pray one for another; let the Head intercede for all.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:161
verses.text: Therefore it is no marvel that he here goes on and shuts the mouths of them that divide the Church of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:162
verses.text: For he that has said, "We have Jesus Christ the righteous, and He is the propitiation for our sins:" having an eye to those who would divide themselves, and would say, "Lo, here is Christ, lo, there;" and would show Him in a part who bought the whole and possesses the whole, he forthwith goes on to say, "Not our sins only, but also the sins of the whole world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:163
verses.text: What is this, brethren? Certainly "we have found it in the fields of the woods," we have found the Church in all nations.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:164
verses.text: Behold, Christ "is the propitiation for our sins; not ours only, but also the sins of the whole world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:165
verses.text: Behold, thou hast the Church throughout the whole world; do not follow false justifiers who in truth are cutters off.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:166
verses.text: Be thou in that mountain which hath filled the whole earth: because "Christ is the propitiation for our sins; not only ours, but also the sins of the whole world," which He hath bought with His blood.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:168
verses.text: "And in this," saith he, "we do know Him, if we keep His commandments".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:169
verses.text: What commandments? "He that saith, I know Him, and keepeth not His commandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:170
verses.text: But still thou askest, What commandments? "But whoso," saith he, "keepeth His word, in him verily is the love of God perfected".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:171
verses.text: Let us see whether this same commandment be not called love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:172
verses.text: For we were asking, what commandments, and he saith, "But whoso keepeth His word, in him verily is the love of God perfected".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:173
verses.text: Mark the Gospel, whether this be not the commandment: "A new commandment," saith the Lord, "give I unto you, that ye love one another.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:174
verses.text: â€”In this we know that we are in Him, if in Him we be perfected".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:175
verses.text: Perfected in love, he calls them: what is perfection of love? To love even enemies, and love them for this end, that they may be brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:176
verses.text: For not a carnal love ought ours to be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:177
verses.text: To wish a man temporal weal, is good; but though that fail, let the soul be safe.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:178
verses.text: Dost thou wish life to any that is thy friend? Thou doest well.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:179
verses.text: Dost thou rejoice at the death of thine enemy? Thou doest ill.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:180
verses.text: But haply both to thy friend the life thou wishest him is not for his good, and to thine enemy the death thou rejoicest at hath been for his good.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:181
verses.text: It is uncertain whether this present life be profitable to any man or unprofitable: but the life which is with God without doubt is profitable.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:182
verses.text: So love thine enemies as to wish them to become thy brethren; so love thine enemies as that they may be called into thy fellowship.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:183
verses.text: For so loved He who, hanging on the cross, said, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:184
verses.text: For he did not say, Father let them live long, me indeed they kill, but let them live.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:185
verses.text: He was casting out from them the death which is for ever and ever, by His most merciful prayer, and by His most surpassing might.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:186
verses.text: Many of them believed, and the shedding of the blood of Christ was forgiven them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:187
verses.text: At first they shed it while they raged; now they drank it while they believed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:188
verses.text: "In this we know that we are in Him, if in Him we be made perfect".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:189
verses.text: Touching the very perfection of love of enemies, the Lord admonishing, saith, "Be ye therefore perfect, as your Heavenly Father is perfect.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:190
verses.text: He," therefore, "that saith he abideth in Him, ought himself also so to walk, even as He walked".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:191
verses.text: How, brethren? what doth he advise us? "He that saith he abideth in Him," i-e:, in Christ, "ought himself also so to walk even as He walked".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:192
verses.text: Haply the advice is this, that we should walk on the sea? That be far from us! It is this then, that we walk in the way of righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:193
verses.text: In what way? I have already mentioned it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:194
verses.text: He was fixed upon the cross, and yet was He walking in this very way: this way is the way of charity, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:195
verses.text: If, therefore, thou have learned to pray for thine enemy, thou walkest in the way of the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:197
verses.text: "Dearly beloved, I write unto you no new commandment, but the old commandment which ye had from the beginning".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:198
verses.text: What commandment calls he "old? Which  ye had," saith he, "from the beginning.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:199
verses.text: Old" then, in this regard, that ye have already heard it: otherwise he will contradict the Lord, where He saith, "A new commandment give I unto you, that ye love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:200
verses.text: But why an "old" commandment? Not as pertaining to the old man.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:201
verses.text: But why? "Which ye had from the beginning.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:202
verses.text: The old commandment is the word which ye have heard".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:203
verses.text: Old then, in this regard, that ye have already heard it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:204
verses.text: And the selfsame he showeth to be new, saying, "Again, a new commandment write I unto you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:205
verses.text: Not another, but the selfsame which he hath called old, the same is also new.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:206
verses.text: Why? "Which thing is true in Him and in you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:207
verses.text: Why old, ye have already heard: i-e:, because ye knew it already.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:208
verses.text: But why new? "Because the darkness is past, and the true light now shineth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:209
verses.text: Lo, whence it is new: because the darkness pertains to the old man, but the light to the new man.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:210
verses.text: What saith the Apostle Paul? "Put ye off the old man, and put ye on the new".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:211
verses.text: And again what saith he? "Ye were sometime darkness, but now light in the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:213
verses.text: "He that saith he is in the light"â€”now he is making all clear that he has been sayingâ€”"he that saith he is in the light, and hateth his brother, is in darkness even until now".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:214
verses.text: What! my brethren, how long shall we say to you, "Love your enemies"? See whether, what is worse, ye do not hate your brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:215
verses.text: If ye loved only your brethren, ye would be not yet perfect: but if ye hate your brethren, what are ye, where are ye? Let each look to his own heart: let him not keep hatred against his brother for any hard word; on account of earthly contention let him not become earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:216
verses.text: For whoso hates his brother, let him not say that he walks in the light.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:217
verses.text: "He that saith he is in the light, and hateth his brother, is in darkness even until now".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:218
verses.text: Thus, some man who was a pagan has become a Christian; mark well: behold he was in darkness, while he was a pagan: now is he made henceforth a Christian; thanks be to God, say all joyfully; the apostle is read, where he saith joyfully, "For ye were sometime darkness, but now light in the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:219
verses.text: Once he worshipped idols, now he worships God; once he worshipped the things he made, now he worships Him that made him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:220
verses.text: He is changed: thanks be to God, say all Christians with joyful greeting.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:221
verses.text: Why? Because henceforth he is one that adores the Father and the Son and the Holy Ghost; one that detests demons and idols.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:222
verses.text: Yet still is John solicitous about our convert: while many greet him with joy, by him he is still looked upon with apprehension.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:223
verses.text: Brethren, let us gladly welcome a mother's solicitude.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:224
verses.text: Not without cause is the mother solicitous about us when others rejoice: by the mother, I mean charity: for she dwelt in the heart of John, when he spake these words.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:225
verses.text: Wherefore, but because there is something he fears in us, even when men now hail us with joy? What is it that he fears? "He that saith he is in the light"â€”What is this? He that saith now he is a Christian,â€”"and hateth his brother, is in darkness even until now".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:226
verses.text: Which there is no need to expound: but to be glad of it, if it be not so, or to bewail it, if it be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:228
verses.text: "He that loveth his brother abideth (manet) in the light, and there is none occasion of stumbling in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:229
verses.text: â€”I beseech you by Christ: God is feeding us, we are about to refresh our bodies in the name of Christ; they both are in some good measure refreshed, and are to be refreshed: let the mind be fed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:230
verses.text: Not that I am going to speak for a long time, do I say this; for behold, the lesson is now coming to an end: but lest haply of weariness we should hear less attentively than we ought that which is most necessary.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:231
verses.text: â€”"He that loveth his brother abideth in the light, and there is no scandal," or "none occasion of stumbling, in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:232
verses.text: Who are they that take scandal or make scandal? They that are offended in Christ, and in the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:233
verses.text: They that are offended in Christ, are as if burnt by the sun, those in the Church as by the moon.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:234
verses.text: But the Psalm saith, "The sun shall not burn thee by day, neither the moon by night: i-e:, if thou hold fast charity, neither in Christ shalt thou have occasion of falling, nor in the Church; neither Christ shalt thou forsake, nor the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:235
verses.text: For he that forsakes the Church, how is he in Christ who is not in the members of Christ? How is he in Christ who is not in the body of Christ? Those therefore take scandal, or, occasion of falling, who forsake Christ or the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:236
verses.text: Whence do we understand that the Psalm in saying, "By day shall the sun not burn thee, nor the moon by night," saith it of this, that the burning means scandal, or occasion of stumbling? In the first place mark the similitude itself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:237
verses.text: Just as the person whom something is burning saith, I cannot bear it, I cannot away with it, and draws back; so those persons  who cannot bear some things in the Church, and withdraw themselves either from the name of Christ or from the Church, are taking scandal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:238
verses.text: For see how those took scandal as from the sun, those carnal ones to whom Christ preached of His flesh, saying, "He that eateth not the flesh of the Son of Man and drinketh His blood, shall have no life in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:239
verses.text: Some seventy persons said, "This is an hard saying," and went back from Him, and there remained the twelve.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:240
verses.text: All those the sun burnt, and they went back, not being able to bear the force of the Word.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:241
verses.text: There remained therefore the twelve.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:242
verses.text: And lest haply men should imagine that they confer a benefit upon Christ by believing on Christ, and not that the benefit is conferred by Him upon them; when the twelve were left, the Lord said to them, "Will ye also go?" That ye may know that I am necessary to you, not ye to me.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:243
verses.text: But those whom the sun had not burnt, answered by the voice of Peter: "Lord, Thou hast the word of eternal life; whither shall we go?" But who are they that the Church as the moon burneth by night? They that have made schisms.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:244
verses.text: Hear the very word used in the apostle: "Who is offended, and I burn not?" In what sense then is it, that there is no scandal or occasion of stumbling in him that loveth his brother? Because he that loveth his brother, beareth all things for unity's sake; because it is in the unity of charity that brotherly love exists.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:245
verses.text: Some one, I know not who, offendeth thee: whether it be a bad man, or as thou supposest a bad man, or as thou pretendest a bad man: and dost thou desert so many good men? What sort of brotherly love is that which hath appeared in these persons? While they accuse the Africans, they have deserted the whole world! What, were there no saints in the whole world? Or was it possible they should be condemned by you unheard? But oh! if ye loved your brethren, there would be none occasion of stumbling in you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:246
verses.text: Hear thou the Psalm, what it saith: "Great peace have they that love Thy law, and there is to them none occasion of stumbling".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:247
verses.text: Great peace it saith there is for them that love the law of God, and that is why there is to them none occasion of stumbling.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:248
verses.text: Those then who take scandal, or, occasion of stumbling, destroy peace.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:249
verses.text: And of whom saith he that they take not and make not occasion of stumbling? They that love God's law.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:250
verses.text: Consequently they are in charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:251
verses.text: But some man will say, "He said it of them that love God's law, not of the brethren".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:252
verses.text: Hear thou what the Lord saith: "A new commandment give I unto you that ye love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:253
verses.text: What is the Law but commandment? Moreover, how is it they do not take occasion of stumbling, but because they forbear one another? As Paul saith, "Forbearing one another in love, studying to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:254
verses.text: And to show that this is the law of Christ, hear the same apostle commending this very law.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:255
verses.text: "Bear ye one another's burdens," saith he, "and so shall ye fulfill the law of Christ".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:257
verses.text: "For he that hateth his brother is in darkness, and walketh in darkness, and knoweth not whither he goeth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:258
verses.text: A great thing, my brethren: mark it, we beseech you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:259
verses.text: "He that hateth his brother walketh in darkness, and knoweth not whither he goeth, because the darkness hath blinded his eyes".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:260
verses.text: What so blind as these who hate their brethren? For that ye may know that they are blind, they have stumbled at a Mountain.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:261
verses.text: I say the same things often, that they may not slip out of your memory.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:262
verses.text: The Stone which was "cut out of the Mountain without hands," is it not Christ, who came of the kingdom of the Jews, without the work of man? Has not that Stone broken in pieces all the kingdoms of the earth, that is, all the dominations of idols and demons? Has not that Stone grown, and become a great mountain, and filled the whole earth? Do we point with the finger to this Mountain in like manner as the moon on its third day is pointed out to men? For example, when they wish people to see the new moon, they say, Lo, the moon! lo, where it is! and if there be some there who are not sharp-sighted, and say, Where? then the finger is put forth that they may see it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:263
verses.text: Sometimes when they are ashamed to be thought blind,  they say they have seen what they have not seen.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:264
verses.text: Do we in this way point out the Church, my brethren? Is it not open? Is it not manifest? Has it not possessed all nations? Is not that fulfilled which so many years before was promised to Abraham, that in his seed should all nations be blessed? It was promised to one believer, and the world is filled with thousands of believers.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:265
verses.text: Behold here the mountain filling the whole face of the earth! Behold the city of which it is said, "A city set upon a mountain cannot be hid!" But those stumble at the mountain, and when it is said to them, Go up; "There is no mountain," say they, and dash their heads against it sooner than seek a habitation there.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:266
verses.text: Esaias was read yesterday; whosoever of you was awake not with his eyes only but with his ear, and not the ear of the body but the ear of the heart, noted this; "In the last days shall the mountain of the house of the Lord be manifest, prepared upon the top of the mountains".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:267
verses.text: 6 What so manifest as a mountain? But there are even mountains unknown, because they are situated in one part of the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:268
verses.text: Which of you knows Mount Olympus? Just as the people who dwell there do not know our Giddaba.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:269
verses.text: These mountains are in different parts of the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:270
verses.text: But not so that Mountain, for it hath filled the whole face of the earth, and of it is said, "Prepared upon the top of the mountains".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:271
verses.text: It is a Mountain above the tops of all mountains.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:272
verses.text: "And," saith he, "to it shall be gathered all nations".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:273
verses.text: Who can fail to be aware of this Mountain? Who breaks his head by stumbling against it? Who is ignorant of the city set upon a mountain? But marvel not that it is unknown by these who hate the brethren, because they walk in darkness and know not whither they go, because the darkness hath blinded their eyes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:274
verses.text: They do not see the Mountain: I would not have thee marvel; they have no eyes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:275
verses.text: How is it they have no eyes? Because the darkness hath blinded them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:276
verses.text: How do we prove this? Because they hate the brethren, in that, while they are offended at Africans, they separate themselves from the whole earth: in that they do not tolerate for the peace of Christ those whom they defame, and do tolerate for the sake of Donatus those whom they condemn.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:277
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:278
verses.text: 1 John II.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:279
verses.text: 12â€“17  "I write unto you, little children, because your sins are forgiven through His name.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:280
verses.text: I write unto you, fathers, because ye have known Him that is from the beginning.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:281
verses.text: I write unto you, young men, because ye have overcome the wicked one.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:282
verses.text: I write unto you, children, because ye have known the Father.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:283
verses.text: I write unto you, fathers, because ye have known Him that is from the beginning.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:284
verses.text: I write unto you, young men, because ye are strong, and the word of God abideth in you, and ye have overcome the wicked one.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:285
verses.text: Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:286
verses.text: If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:287
verses.text: For all that is in the world, is the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, which is not of the Father, but is of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:288
verses.text: And the world passeth away, and the lust thereof: but he that doeth the will of God abideth for ever (even as God also abideth for ever).

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:290
verses.text: All things that are read from the Holy Scriptures in order to our instruction and salvation, it behoves us to hear with earnest heed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:291
verses.text: Yet most of all must those things be commended to our memory, which are of most force against heretics; whose insidious designs cease not to circumvent all that are weaker and more negligent.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:292
verses.text: Remember that our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ both died for us, and rose again; died, to wit, for our offenses, rose again for our justification.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:293
verses.text: Even as ye have just heard concerning the  two disciples whom He met with in the way, how "their eyes were holden that they should not know Him:" and He found them despairing of the redemption that was in Christ, and deeming that now He had suffered and was dead as a man, not accounting that as Son of God He ever liveth; and deeming too that He was so dead in the flesh as not to come to life again, but just as one of the prophets: as those of you who were attentive have just now heard their own words.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:294
verses.text: Then "He opened to them the Scriptures, beginning at Moses," and going through all the prophets, showing them that all He had suffered had been foretold, lest they should be more staggered if the Lord should rise again, and the more fail to believe Him, if these things had not been told before concerning Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:295
verses.text: For the firmness of faith is in this, that all things which came to pass in Christ were foretold.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:296
verses.text: The disciples, then, knew Him not, save "in the breaking of bread".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:297
verses.text: And truly he that eateth and drinketh not judgment to himself in the breaking of bread doth know Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:298
verses.text: Afterward also those eleven "thought they saw a spirit".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:299
verses.text: He gave Himself to be handled by them, who also gave Himself to be crucified; to be crucified by enemies, to be handled by friends: yet the Physician of all, both of the ungodliness of those, and of the unbelief of these.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:300
verses.text: For ye heard when the Acts of the Apostles were read, how many thousands of Christ's slayers believed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:301
verses.text: If those believed afterwards who had killed, should not those believe who for a little while doubted? And yet even in regard of them, (a thing which ye ought especially to observe, and to commit to your memory, because that which shall make us strong against insidious errors, God has been pleased to put in the Scriptures, against which no man dares to speak, who in any sort wishes to seem a Christian), when He had given Himself to be handled by them, that did not suffice Him, but He would also confirm by means of the Scriptures the heart of them that believe: for He looked forward to us who should be afterwards; seeing that in Him we have nothing that we can handle, but have that which we may read.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:302
verses.text: For if those believed only because they held and handled, what shall we do? Now, Christ is ascended into heaven; He is not to come save at the end, to judge the quick and the dead.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:303
verses.text: Whereby shall we believe, but by that whereby it was His will that even those who handled Him should be confirmed? For He opened to them the Scriptures and showed them that it behoved Christ to suffer, and that all things should be fulfilled which were written of Him in the Law of Moses, and the Prophets, and the Psalms.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:304
verses.text: He embraced in His discourse the whole ancient text of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:305
verses.text: All that there is of those former Scriptures tells of Christ; but only if it find ears.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:306
verses.text: He also "opened their understanding that they might understand the Scriptures".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:307
verses.text: Whence we also must pray for this, that He would open our understanding.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:309
verses.text: But what did the Lord show written of Him in the Law of Moses, and the Prophets, and the Psalms? What did He show? Let Himself say.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:310
verses.text: The evangelist has put this briefly, that we might know what in all that great compass of the Scriptures we ought to believe and to understand.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:311
verses.text: Certainly there are many pages, and many books; the contents of them all is this which the Lord briefly spake to His disciples.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:312
verses.text: What is this? That "it behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise again the third day".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:313
verses.text: Thou hast it now concerning the Bridegroom, that "it behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise again:" the Bridegroom has been set forth to us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:314
verses.text: Concerning the Bride, let us see what He saith; that thou, when thou knowest the Bridegroom and the Bride, mayest not without reason come to the marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:315
verses.text: For every celebration is a celebration of marriage: the Church's nuptials are celebrated.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:316
verses.text: The King's Son is about to marry a wife, and that King's Son is Himself a King: and the guests frequenting the marriage are themselves the Bride.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:317
verses.text: Not, as in a carnal marriage, some are guests, and another is she that is married; in the Church they that come as guests, if they come to good purpose, become the Bride.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:318
verses.text: For all the Church is Christ's Bride, of which the beginning and first fruits is the flesh of Christ: there was the Bride joined to the Bridegroom in the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:319
verses.text: With good reason when He would betoken that same flesh, He brake bread, and with good reason "in the breaking of bread," the eyes "of the disciples were opened, and they knew Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:320
verses.text: Well then, what did the Lord say was written of Him in the Law and Prophets and Psalms? That "it behoved Christ to suffer".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:321
verses.text: Had He not added, "and to rise again," well might those mourn whose eyes were holden; but "to rise again" is also foretold.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:322
verses.text: And wherefore this? Why did it behove Christ to suffer and to rise again? Because of that Psalm which we especially commended to your attention on the fourth day, the first station, of last week.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:323
verses.text: Why did it behove  Christ to suffer and to rise again? For this reason: "All the ends of the earth shall be reminded and converted unto the Lord, and all the kindreds of the nations shall worship before Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:324
verses.text: For that ye may know that it behoved Christ to suffer and to rise again; in this place also what hath He added, that after setting forth the Bridegroom He might also set forth the Bride? "And that there be preached," saith He, "in His name, repentance and remission of sins throughout all nations, beginning at Jerusalem".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:325
verses.text: Ye have heard, brethren; hold it fast.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:326
verses.text: Let no man doubt concerning the Church, that it is "throughout all nations:" let no man doubt that it began at Jerusalem, and hath filled all nations.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:327
verses.text: We know the field where the Vine is planted: but when it is grown we know it not, because it has taken up the whole.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:328
verses.text: Whence did it begin? "At Jerusalem".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:329
verses.text: Whither has it come? To "all nations".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:330
verses.text: A few remain: it shall possess all.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:331
verses.text: In the mean time, while it is taking possession of all, it has seemed good to the Husbandman to cut off some unprofitable branches, and they have made heresies and schisms.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:332
verses.text: Let not the branches that are cut off induce you to be cut off: rather exhort ye them that are cut off that they be grafted in again.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:333
verses.text: It is manifest that Christ hath suffered, is risen again, and is ascended into heaven: made manifest also is the Church, because there is "preached in His name repentance and remission of sins throughout all nations".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:334
verses.text: Whence did it begin? "Beginning at Jerusalem".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:335
verses.text: The man hears this; foolish and vain, and (how, shall I express it?) worse than blind! so great a mountain, and he does not see it; a candle set upon a candlestick, and he shuts his eyes against it!  3.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:336
verses.text: When we say to them, If ye be Catholic Christians, communicate with that Church from which the Gospel is spread abroad over the whole earth: communicate with that Jerusalem: when this we say to them, they make answer to us, we do not communicate with that city where our King was slain, where our Lord was slain: as though they hate the city where our Lord was slain.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:337
verses.text: The Jews slew Him whom they found on earth, these scorn Him that sitteth in heaven! Which are the worse; those who despised Him because they thought Him man, or those who scorn the sacraments of Him whom now they confess to be God? But they hate, forsooth, the city in which their Lord was slain! Pious men, and merciful! they much grieve that Christ was slain, and in men they slay Christ! But He loved that city, and pitied it: from it He bade the preaching of Him begin, "beginning at Jerusalem".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:338
verses.text: He made there the beginning of the preaching of His name: and thou shrinkest back with horror from having communion with that city! No marvel that being cut off thou hatest the root.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:339
verses.text: What said He to His disciples? "Sit ye still in the city, because I send my promise upon you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:340
verses.text: Behold what the city is that they hate! Haply they would love it, if Christ's murderers dwelt in it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:341
verses.text: For it is manifest that all Christ's murderers, i-e:, the Jews, are expelled from that city.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:342
verses.text: That which had in it them that were fierce against Christ, hath now them that adore Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:343
verses.text: Therefore do these men hate it, because Christians are in it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:344
verses.text: There was it His will that His disciples should tarry, and there that He should send to them the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:345
verses.text: Where had the Church its commencement, but where the Holy Ghost came from heaven, and filled the hundred and twenty sitting in one place? That number twelve was made tenfold.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:346
verses.text: They sat, an hundred and twenty persons, and the Holy Ghost came, "and filled the whole place, and there came a sound, as it were the rushing of a mighty wind, and there were cloven tongues like as of fire".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:347
verses.text: Ye have heard the Acts of the Apostles: this was the lesson read today: "They began to speak with tongues as the Spirit gave them utterance".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:348
verses.text: And all who were on the spot, Jews who were come from divers nations, recognised each his own tongue, and marvelled that those unlearned and ignorant men had on the sudden learned not one or two tongues, but the tongues of all nations whatsoever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:349
verses.text: There, then, where all tongues sounded, there was it betokened that all tongues should believe.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:350
verses.text: But these men, who much love Christ, and therefore refuse to communicate with the city which killed Christ, so honor Christ as to affirm that He is left to two tongues, the Latin and the Punic, i-e: African.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:351
verses.text: Christ possess only two tongues! For there are but these two tongues on the side of Donatus, more they have not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:352
verses.text: Let us awake, my brethren, let us rather see the gift of the Spirit of God, and let us believe the things spoken before concerning Him, and let us see fulfilled the things spoken before in the Psalm: "There are neither speeches nor discourses but their voices are heard among them".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:353
verses.text: And lest haply the case  be so that the tongues themselves came to one place, and not rather that the gift of Christ came to all tongues, hear what follows: "Into all the earth is their sound gone out, and unto the ends of the world their words".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:354
verses.text: Wherefore this? Because "in the sun hath He set His tabernacle," i-e:, in the open light.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:355
verses.text: His tabernacle, His flesh: His tabernacle, His Church: "in the sun" it is set; not in the night, but in the day.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:356
verses.text: But why do those not acknowledge it? Return to the lesson at the place where it ended yesterday, and see why they do not acknowledge it: "He that hateth his brother, walketh in darkness, and knoweth not whither he goeth, because the darkness hath blinded his eyes".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:357
verses.text: For us then, let us see what follows, and not be in darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:358
verses.text: How shall we not be in darkness? If we love the brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:359
verses.text: How is it proved that we love the brotherhood? By this, that we do not rend unity, that we hold fast charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:361
verses.text: "I write unto you, little children, because your sins are forgiven you through His name".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:362
verses.text: Therefore, "little children," because in forgiveness of sins ye have your birth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:363
verses.text: But through whose name are sins forgiven? Through Augustin's? No, therefore neither through the name of Donatus.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:364
verses.text: Be it thy concern to see who is Augustin, or who Donatus: no, not through the name of Paul, not through the name of Peter.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:365
verses.text: For to them that divided unto themselves the Church, and out of unity essayed to make parties, the mother charity in the apostle travailing in birth with her little ones, exposeth her own bowels, with words doth as it were rend her breasts, bewaileth her children whom she seeth borne out dead, recalleth unto the one Name them that would needs make them many names, repelleth them from the love of her that Christ may be loved, and saith, "Was Paul crucified for you? Or were ye baptized in the name of Paul?" What saith he? "I would not that ye be mine, that so ye may be with me: be ye with me; all we are His who died for us, who was crucified for us": whence here also it is said, "Your sins are forgiven you through His name," not through the name of any man.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:367
verses.text: "I write unto you, fathers".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:368
verses.text: Why first sons? "Because your sins are forgiven you through His name," and ye are regenerated into a new life, therefore sons.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:369
verses.text: Why fathers? "Because ye have known Him that is from the beginning:" for the beginning hath relation unto fatherhood.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:370
verses.text: Christ new in flesh, but ancient in Godhead.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:371
verses.text: How ancient think we? how many years old? Think we, of greater age than His mother? Assuredly of greater age than His mother, for "all things were made by Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:372
verses.text: If all things, then did the Ancient make the very mother of whom the New should be born.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:373
verses.text: Was He, think we, before His mother only? Yea, and before His mother's ancestors is His antiquity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:374
verses.text: The ancestor of His mother was Abraham; and the Lord saith, "Before Abraham I am".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:375
verses.text: Before Abraham, say we? The heaven and earth, ere man was, were made.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:376
verses.text: Before these was the Lord, nay rather also is.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:377
verses.text: For right well He saith, not, Before Abraham I was, but, "Before Abraham I Am".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:378
verses.text: For that of which one says, "was," is not; and that of which one says, "will be," is not yet: He knoweth not other than to be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:379
verses.text: As God, He knoweth "to be:" "was," and "will be," He knoweth not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:380
verses.text: It is one day there, but a day that is for ever and ever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:381
verses.text: That day yesterday and tomorrow do not set in the midst between them: for when the 'yesterday' is ended, the 'to-day' begins, to be finished by the coming 'tomorrow.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:382
verses.text: ' That one day there is a day without darkness, without night, without spaces, without measure, without hours.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:383
verses.text: Call it what thou wilt: if thou wilt, it is a day; if thou wilt, a year; if thou wilt, years.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:384
verses.text: For it is said of this same, "And thy years shall not fail".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:385
verses.text: But when is it called a day? When it is said to the Lord, "To-day have I begotten Thee".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:386
verses.text: From the eternal Father begotten, from eternity begotten, in eternity begotten: with no beginning, no bound, no space of breadth; because He is what is, because Himself is "He that Is".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:387
verses.text: This His name He told to Moses: "Thou shalt say unto them, He that Is hath sent me unto you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:388
verses.text: Why speak then of "before Abraham"? why, before Noe? why, before Adam? Hear the Scripture: "Before the day-star have I begotten Thee".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:389
verses.text: In fine, before heaven and earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:390
verses.text: Wherefore? Because "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:391
verses.text: By this know ye the "fathers:" for they become fathers by acknowledging "That which is from the beginning".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:393
verses.text: "I write unto you, young men".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:394
verses.text: There are sons, are fathers, are young men: sons, because begotten; fathers, because they acknowledge the Beginning; why young men? "Because ye have overcome the wicked one".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:395
verses.text: In the sons, birth: in the fathers, antiquity: in the young men, strength.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:396
verses.text: If the wicked one is "overcome" by the young men, he  fights with us.
