verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:815
verses.text: And wherefore was He not known? Because He reproved all sins in men.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:816
verses.text: They, through loving the delights of sins, did not acknowledge the God: through loving that which the fever prompted, they did wrong to the Physician.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:818
verses.text: For us then, what are we? Already we are begotten of Him; but because we are such in hope, he saith, "Beloved, now are we sons of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:819
verses.text: Now already? Then what is it we look for, if already we are sons of God? "And not yet," saith he, "is it manifested what we shall be".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:820
verses.text: But what else shall we be than sons of God? Hear what follows: "We know that, when He shall appear, we shall be like Him, because we shall see Him as He is".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:821
verses.text: Understand, my beloved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:822
verses.text: It is a great matter: "We know that, when He shall appear, we shall be like Him; for we shall see Him as He is".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:823
verses.text: In the first place mark, what is called "Is".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:824
verses.text: Ye know what it is that is so called.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:825
verses.text: That which is called "Is," and not only is called but is so, is unchangeable: It ever remaineth, It cannot be changed, It is in no part corruptible: It hath neither proficiency, for It is perfect; nor hath deficiency, for It is eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:826
verses.text: And what is this? "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:827
verses.text: And what is this? "Who being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:828
verses.text: To see Christ in this sort, Christ in the form of God, Word of God, Only-Begotten of the Father, equal with the Father, is to the bad impossible.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:829
verses.text: But in regard that the Word was made flesh, the bad also shall have power to see Him: because in the day of judgment the bad also will see Him; for He shall so come to judge, as He came to be judged.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:830
verses.text: In the selfsame form, a man, but yet God: for "cursed is every one that putteth his trust in man".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:831
verses.text: A man, He came to be judged, a man, He will come to judge.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:832
verses.text: And if He shall not be seen, what is this that is written, "They shall look on Him whom they pierced?" For of the ungodly it is said, that they shall see and be confounded.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:833
verses.text: How shall the ungodly not see, when He shall set some on the right hand, others on the left? To those on the right hand He will say, "Come, ye blessed of my Father, receive the kingdom:" to those on the left He will say, "Go into everlasting fire".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:834
verses.text: They will see but the form of a servant, the form of God they will not see.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:835
verses.text: Why? because they were ungodly; and the Lord Himself saith, "Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:836
verses.text: Therefore, we are to see a certain vision, my brethren, "which neither eye hath seen, nor ear hath heard, nor hath entered into the heart of man:" a certain vision, a vision surpassing all earthly beautifulness, of gold, of silver, of groves and fields; the beautifulness of sea and air, the beautifulness of sun and moon, the beautifulness of the stars, the beautifulness of angels: surpassing all things: because from it are all things beautiful.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:838
verses.text: What then shall "we" be, when we shall see this? What is promised to us? "We shall be like Him, for we shall see Him as He is".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:839
verses.text: The tongue hath done what it could, hath sounded the words: let the rest be thought by the heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:840
verses.text: For what hath even John himself said in comparison of That which Is, or what can be said by us men, who are so far from being equal to his merits? Return we therefore to that unction of Him, return we to that unction which inwardly teacheth that which we cannot speak: and because ye cannot at present see, let your part and duty be in desire.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:841
verses.text: The whole life of a good Christian is an holy desire.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:842
verses.text: Now  what thou longest for, thou dost not yet see: howbeit by longing, thou art made capable, so that when that is come which thou mayest see, thou shall be filled.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:843
verses.text: For just as, if thou wouldest fill a bag, and knowest how great the thing is that shall be given, thou stretchest the opening of the sack or the skin, or whatever else it be; thou knowest how much thou wouldest put in, and seest that the bag is narrow; by stretching thou makest it capable of holding more: so God, by deferring our hope, stretches our desire; by the desiring, stretches the mind; by stretching, makes it more capacious.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:844
verses.text: Let us desire therefore, my brethren, for we shall be filled.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:845
verses.text: See Paul widening, as it were, his bosom, that it may be able to receive that which is to come.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:846
verses.text: He saith, namely, "Not that I have already received, or am already perfect: brethren, I deem not myself to have apprehended".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:847
verses.text: Then what art thou doing in this life, if thou have not yet apprehended? "But this one thing [I do]; forgetting the things that are behind, reaching forth to the things that are before, upon the strain I follow on unto the prize of the high calling".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:848
verses.text: He says he reaches forth, or stretches himself, and says that he follows "upon the strain".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:849
verses.text: He felt himself too little to take in that "which eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither hath entered into the heart of man".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:850
verses.text: This is our life, that by longing we should be exercised.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:851
verses.text: But holy longing exercises us just so much as we prune off our longings from the love of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:852
verses.text: We have already said, "Empty out that which is to be filled".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:853
verses.text: With good thou art to be filled: pour out the bad.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:854
verses.text: Suppose that God would fill thee with honey: if thou art full of vinegar, where wilt thou put the honey? That which the vessel bore in it must be poured out: the vessel itself must be cleansed; must be cleansed, albeit with labor, albeit with hard rubbing, that it may become fit for that thing, whatever it be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:855
verses.text: Let us say honey, say gold, say wine; whatever we say it is, being that which cannot be said, whatever we would fain say, It is calledâ€”God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:856
verses.text: And when we say "God," what have we said? Is that one syllable the whole of that we look for? So then, whatever we have had power to say is beneath Him: let us stretch ourselves unto Him, that when He shall come, He may fill us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:857
verses.text: For "we shall be like Him; because we shall see Him as He is".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:859
verses.text: "And every one that hath this hope in Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:860
verses.text: Ye see how he hath set us our place, in "hope".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:861
verses.text: Ye see how the Apostle Paul agreeth with his fellow-apostle, "By hope we are saved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:862
verses.text: But hope that is seen, is not hope: for what a man seeth, why doth he hope for? For if what we see not, we hope for, by patience we wait for it".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:863
verses.text: This very patience exerciseth desire.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:864
verses.text: Continue thou, for He continueth: and persevere thou in walking, that thou mayest reach the goal: for that to which thou tendest will not remove.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:865
verses.text: See: "And every one that hath this hope in Him, purifieth himself even as He is pure".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:866
verses.text: See how he has not taken away free-will, in that he saith, "purifieth himself".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:867
verses.text: Who purifieth us but God? Yea, but God doth not purify thee if thou be unwilling.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:868
verses.text: Therefore, in that thou joinest thy will to God, in that thou purifiest thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:869
verses.text: Thou purifiest thyself, not by thyself, but by Him who cometh to inhabit thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:870
verses.text: Still, because thou doest somewhat therein by the will, therefore is somewhat attributed to thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:871
verses.text: But it is attributed to thee only to the end thou shouldest say, as in the Psalm, "Be thou my helper, forsake me not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:872
verses.text: If thou sayest, "Be thou my helper," thou doest somewhat: for if thou be doing nothing, how should He be said to "help" thee?  8.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:873
verses.text: "Every one that doeth sin, doeth also iniquity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:874
verses.text: Let no man say, Sin is one thing, iniquity another: let no man say, I am a sinful man, but not a doer of iniquity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:875
verses.text: For, "Every one that doeth sin, doeth also iniquity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:876
verses.text: Sin is iniquity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:877
verses.text: Well then, what are we to do concerning sins and iniquities? Hear what He saith: "And ye know that He was manifested to take away sin; and sin in Him is not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:878
verses.text: He, in Whom sin is not, the same is come to take away sin.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:879
verses.text: For were there sin in Him, it must be taken away from Him, not He take it away Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:880
verses.text: "Whosoever abideth in Him, sinneth not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:881
verses.text: In so far as he abideth in Him, in so far sinneth not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:882
verses.text: "Whosoever sinneth hath not seen Him, neither known Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:883
verses.text: A great question this: "Whosoever sinneth hath not seen Him, neither known Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:884
verses.text: No marvel.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:885
verses.text: We have not seen Him, but are to see; have not known Him, but are to know: we believe on One we have not known.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:886
verses.text: Or haply, by faith we have known, and by actual beholding have not yet known? But then in faith we have both seen and known.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:887
verses.text: For if faith doth not yet see, why are we said to have been enlightened? There is an enlightening by faith, and an enlightening by sight.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:888
verses.text: At present, while we are on pilgrimage, "we walk by faith, not by sight,"  or, actually beholding.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:889
verses.text: Therefore also our righteousness is "by faith, not by sight".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:890
verses.text: Our righteousness shall be perfect, when we shall see by actual beholding.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:891
verses.text: Only, in the meanwhile, let us not leave that righteousness which is of faith, since "the just doth live by faith," as saith the apostle.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:892
verses.text: "Whosoever abideth in Him, sinneth not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:893
verses.text: For, "whosoever sinneth, hath not seen Him, neither known Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:894
verses.text: That man who sins, believes not: but if a man believes, so far as pertains to his faith, he sinneth not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:896
verses.text: "Little children, let no man seduce you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:897
verses.text: He that doeth righteousness is righteous, as He is righteous".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:898
verses.text: What, on hearing that we are "righteous as He is righteous," are we to think ourselves equal with God? Ye must know what means that "as:" thus he said a while ago, "Purifieth himself even as He is pure".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:899
verses.text: Then is our purity like and equal to the purity of God, and our righteousness to God's righteousness? Who can say this? But the word "as," is not always wont to be used in the sense of equality.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:900
verses.text: As, for example, if, having seen this large church,  a person should wish to build a smaller church, but with the same relative dimensions: as, for example, if this be one measure in width and two measures in length, he too should build his church one measure in width and two measures in length: in that case one sees that he has built it "as" this is built.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:901
verses.text: But this church has, say, a hundred cubits in length, the other thirty: it is at once "as" this, and yet unequal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:902
verses.text: Ye see that this "as" is not always referred to parity and equality.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:903
verses.text: For example, see what a difference there is between the face of a man and its image from a mirror: there is a face in the image, a face in the body: the image exists in imitation, the body in reality.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:904
verses.text: And what do we say? Why, "as" there are eyes here, so also there; "as" ears here, so ears also there.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:905
verses.text: The thing is different, but the "as" is said of the resemblance.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:906
verses.text: Well then, we also have in us the image of God; but not that which the Son equal with the Father hath: yet except we also, according to our measure, were "as" He, we should in no respect be said to be like Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:907
verses.text: "He purifieth us," then, "even as He is pure:" but He is pure from eternity, we pure by faith.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:908
verses.text: We are "righteous even as He is righteous;" but He is so in His immutable perpetuity, we righteous by believing on One we do not see, that so we may one day see Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:909
verses.text: Even when our righteousness shall be perfect, when we shall be equal to the angels, not even then shall it be equalled with Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:910
verses.text: How far then is it from Him now, when not even then it shall be equal!  10.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:911
verses.text: "He that doeth sin, is of the devil, because the devil sinneth from the beginning".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:912
verses.text: "Is of the devil:" ye know what he means: by imitating the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:913
verses.text: For the devil made no man, begat no man, created no man: but whoso imitates the devil, that person, as if begotten of him, becomes a child of the devil; by imitating him, not literally by being begotten of him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:914
verses.text: In what sense art thou a child of Abraham, not that Abraham begat thee? In the same sense as the Jews, the children of Abraham, not imitating the faith of Abraham, are become children of the devil: of the flesh of Abraham they were begotten, and the faith of Abraham they have not imitated.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:915
verses.text: If then those who were thence begotten were put out of the inheritance, because they did not imitate, thou, who art not begotten of him, art made a child, and in this way shall be a child of him by imitating him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:916
verses.text: And if thou imitate the devil, in such wise as he became proud and impious against God, thou wilt be a child of the devil: by imitating, not that he created thee or begat thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:918
verses.text: "Unto this end was the Son of God manifested".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:919
verses.text: Now then, brethren, mark! All sinners are begotten of the devil, as sinners.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:920
verses.text: Adam was made by God: but when he consented to the devil, he was begotten of the devil; and he begat all men such as he was himself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:921
verses.text: With lust itself we were born; even before we add our sins, from that condemnation we have our birth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:922
verses.text: For if we are born without any sin, wherefore this running with infants to baptism that they may be released? Then mark well, brethren, the two birth-stocks, Adam and Christ: two men are; but one of them, a man that is man; the other, a Man that is God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:923
verses.text: By the man that is man we are sinners; by the Man that is God we are justified.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:924
verses.text: That birth hath cast down unto death; this birth hath raised up unto life: that birth brings with it sin; this birth setteth free from sin.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:925
verses.text: For to this end came Christ as Man, to undo the sins of men.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:926
verses.text: "Unto this end was the Son of God manifested, that He may undo the works of the devil".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:928
verses.text: The rest I commend to your thoughts, my beloved, that I may not burden you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:929
verses.text: For the question we labor to solve is even thisâ€”that we call ourselves sinners: for if any man shall say that he is without sin, he is a liar.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:930
verses.text: And in the Epistle of this same John we have found it written, "If we say that we  have no sin, we deceive ourselves".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:931
verses.text: For ye should remember what went before: "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:932
verses.text: And yet, on the other hand, in what follows thou art told, "He that is begotten of God sinneth not: he that doeth sin hath not seen Him, neither known Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:933
verses.text: â€”Every one that doeth sin is of the devil:" sin is not of God: this affrights us again.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:934
verses.text: In what sense are we begotten of God, and in what sense do we confess ourselves sinners? Shall we say, because we are not begotten of God? And what do these Sacraments in regard to infants? What hath John said? "He that is begotten of God, sinneth not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:935
verses.text: And yet again the same John hath said, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us!" A great question it is, and an embarrassing one; and may I have made you intent upon having it solved, my beloved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:936
verses.text: Tomorrow, in the name of the Lord, what He will give, we will discourse thereof.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:937
verses.text: Homily V.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:938
verses.text: 1 John III.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:939
verses.text: 9â€“18  "Whosoever is born of God doth not commit sin; for his seed remaineth in him: and he cannot sin, because he is born of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:940
verses.text: In this the children of God are manifest, and the children of the devil: whosoever is not righteous is not of God, neither he that loveth not his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:941
verses.text: For this is the message that ye heard from the beginning, that we should love one another.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:942
verses.text: Not as Cain, who was of the wicked one, and slew his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:943
verses.text: And wherefore slew he him? Because his own works were evil, and his brother's righteous.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:944
verses.text: Marvel not, my brethren, if the world hate us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:945
verses.text: We know that we have passed from death unto life, because we love the brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:946
verses.text: He that loveth not abideth in death.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:947
verses.text: Whosoever hateth his brother is a murderer: and ye know that no murderer hath eternal life abiding in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:948
verses.text: In this we know love, that He laid down His life for us: and we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:949
verses.text: But whoso hath this world's good, and seeth his brother have need, and shutteth up his bowels of compassion from him, how can the love of God dwell in him? My little children, let us not love only in word and in tongue; but in deed and in truth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:951
verses.text: Hear intently, I do beseech you, because it is no small matter that we have to cope withal: and I doubt not, because ye were intent upon it yesterday, that ye have with even greater intentness of purpose come together to-day.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:952
verses.text: For it is no slight question, how he saith in this Epistle, "Whosoever is born of God, sinneth not," and how in the same Epistle he hath said above, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:953
verses.text: What shall the man do, who is pressed by both sayings out of the same Epistle? If he shall confess himself a sinner, he fears lest it be said to him, Then art thou not born of God; because it is written, "Whosoever is born of God, sinneth not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:954
verses.text: But if he shall say that he is just and that he hath no sin, he receives on the other side a blow from the same Epistle, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:955
verses.text: Placed then as he is in the midst, what he can say and what confess, or what profess, he cannot find.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:956
verses.text: To profess himself to be without sin, is full of peril; and not only full of peril, but also full of error: "We deceive ourselves," saith he, "and the truth is not in us, if we say that we have no sin".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:957
verses.text: But oh that thou hadst none, and saidst this! for then wouldest thou say truly, and in uttering the truth wouldest have not so much as a vestige of wrong to be afraid of.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:958
verses.text: But, that thou doest ill if thou say so, is because it is a lie that thou sayest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:959
verses.text: "The truth," saith he, "is not in us, if we say that we have no sin".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:960
verses.text: He saith not, "Have not had;"  lest haply it should seem to be spoken of the past life.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:961
verses.text: For the man here hath had sins: but from the time that he was born of God, he has begun not to have sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:962
verses.text: If it were so, there would be no question to embarrass us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:963
verses.text: For we should say, We have been sinners, but now we are justified: we have had sin, but now we have none.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:964
verses.text: He saith not this: but what saith he? "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:965
verses.text: And then after a while he says on the other hand, "Whosoever is born of God sinneth not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:966
verses.text: Was John himself not born of God? If John was not born of God, John, of whom ye have heard that he lay in the Lord's bosom; does any man dare engage for himself that in him has taken place that regeneration which it was not granted to that man to have, to whom it was granted to lie in the bosom of the Lord? The man whom the Lord loved more than the rest, him alone had He not begotten of the Spirit?  2.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:967
verses.text: Mark now these words.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:968
verses.text: As yet, I am urging it upon you, what straits we are put to that by putting your minds on the stretch, that is, by your praying for us and for yourselves, God may make enlargement, and give us an outlet: lest some man find in His word an occasion of his own perdition, that word which was preached and put in writing only for healing and salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:969
verses.text: "Every man," saith he, "that doeth sin, doeth also iniquity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:970
verses.text: Lest haply thou make a distinction, "Sin is iniquity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:971
verses.text: Lest thou say, A sinner I am, but not a doer of iniquity, "Sin is iniquity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:972
verses.text: And ye know that to this end was He manifested, that He should take away sin; and there is no sin in Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:973
verses.text: And what doth it profit us, that He came without sin? "Every one that sinneth not, abideth in Him: and every one that sinneth, hath not seen Him, neither known Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:974
verses.text: Little children, let no man seduce you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:975
verses.text: He that doeth righteousness is righteous, even as He is righteous".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:976
verses.text: This we have already said, that the word "as" is wont to be used of a certain resemblance, not of equality.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:977
verses.text: "He that doeth sin is of the devil, because the devil sinneth from the beginning".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:978
verses.text: This too we have already said, that the devil created no man, nor begat any, but his imitators are, as it were, born of him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:979
verses.text: "To this end was the Son of God manifested, that He should undo the works of the devil".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:980
verses.text: Consequently, to undo (or loose) sins, He that hath no sin.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:981
verses.text: And then follows: "Every one that is born of God doth not commit sin; for his seed remaineth in him: and he cannot sin, because he is born of God:" he has drawn the cord tight!â€”Belike, it is in regard of some one sin that he hath said, "Doth not sin," not in regard of all sin: that in this that he saith, "Whoso is born of God, doth not sin," thou mayest understand some one particular sin, which that man who is born of God cannot commit: and such is that sin that, if one commit it, it confirms the rest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:982
verses.text: What is this sin? To do contrary to the commandment.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:983
verses.text: What is the commandment? "A new commandment give I unto you, that ye love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:984
verses.text: Mark well! This commandment of Christ is called, "love".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:985
verses.text: By this love sins are loosed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:986
verses.text: If this love be not kept, the not holding it is at once a grievous sin, and the root of all sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:988
verses.text: Mark well, brethren; we have brought forward somewhat in which, to them that have good understanding, the question is solved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:989
verses.text: But do we only walk in the way with them that run more swiftly? Those that walk more slowly must not be left behind.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:990
verses.text: Let us turn the matter every way, in such words as we can, in order that it may be brought within reach of all.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:991
verses.text: For I suppose, brethren, that every man is concerned for his own soul, who does not come to Church without cause, who does not seek temporal things in the Church, who does not come here to transact secular business; but comes here in order that he may lay hold upon some eternal thing, promised unto him, whereunto he may attain: he must needs consider how he shall walk in the way, lest he be left behind, lest he go back, lest he go astray, lest by halting he do not attain.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:992
verses.text: Whoever therefore is in earnest, let him be slow, let him be swift, yet let him not leave the way.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:993
verses.text: This then I have said, that  in saying, "Whosoever is born of God sinneth not," it is probable he meant it of some particular sin: for else it will be contrary to that place: "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:994
verses.text: In this way then the question may be solved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:995
verses.text: There is a certain sin, which he that is born of God cannot commit; a sin, which not being committed, other sins are loosed, and being committed, other sins are confirmed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:996
verses.text: What is this sin? To do contrary to the commandment of Christ, contrary to the New Testament.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:997
verses.text: What is the new commandment? "A new commandment give I unto you, that ye love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:998
verses.text: Whoso doeth contrary to charity and contrary to brotherly love, let him not dare to glory and say that he is born of God: but whoso is in brotherly love, there are certain sins which he cannot commit, and this above all, that he should hate his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:999
verses.text: And how fares it with him concerning his other sins, of which it is said, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us?" Let him hear that which shall set his mind at rest from another place of Scripture; "Charity covereth a multitude of sins".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1001
verses.text: Charity therefore we commend; charity this Epistle commendeth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1002
verses.text: The Lord, after His resurrection, what question put He to Peter, but, "Lovest thou me?" And it was not enough to ask it once; a second time also He put none other question, a third time also none other.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1003
verses.text: Although when it came to the third time, Peter, as one who knew not what was the drift of this, was grieved because it seemed as if the Lord did not believe him; nevertheless both a first time and a second, and a third He put this question.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1004
verses.text: Thrice fear denied, thrice love confessed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1005
verses.text: Behold Peter loveth the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1006
verses.text: What is he to do for the Lord? For think not that he in the Psalm did not feel himself at a loss what to do: "What shall I render unto the Lord for all the benefits He hath done unto me?" He that said this in the Psalm, marked what great things had been done for him by God; and sought what he should render to God, and could find nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1007
verses.text: For whatever thou wouldest render, from Him didst thou receive it to render.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1008
verses.text: And what did he find to offer in return? That which, as we said, my brethren, he had received from Him, that only found he to offer in return.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1009
verses.text: "I will receive the cup of salvation, and will call upon the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1010
verses.text: For who had given him the cup of salvation, but He to whom he wished to offer in return? Now to receive the cup of salvation, and call upon the name of the Lord, is to be filled with charity; and so filled, that not only thou shalt not hate thy brother, but shall be prepared to die for thy brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1011
verses.text: This is perfect charity, that thou be prepared to die for thy brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1012
verses.text: This the Lord exhibited in Himself, who died for all, praying for them by whom He was crucified, and saying, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1013
verses.text: But if He alone hath done this, He was not a Master, if He had no disciples.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1014
verses.text: Disciples who came after Him have done this.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1015
verses.text: Men were stoning Stephen, and he knelt down and said, "Lord, lay not this sin to their charge".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1016
verses.text: He loved them that were killing him; since for them also he was dying.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1017
verses.text: Hear also the Apostle Paul: "And I myself," saith he, "will be spent for your souls".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1018
verses.text: For he was among those for whom Stephen, when by their hands he was dying, besought forgiveness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1019
verses.text: This then is perfect charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1020
verses.text: If any man shall have so great charity that he is prepared even to die for his brethren, in that man is perfect charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1021
verses.text: But as soon as it is born, is it already quite perfect? That it may be made perfect, it is born; when born, it is nourished; when nourished, it is strengthened; when strengthened, it is perfected; when it has come to perfection, what saith it? "To me to live is Christ, and to die is gain.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1022
verses.text: I wished to be dissolved, and to be with Christ; which is far better: nevertheless to abide in the flesh is needful for you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1023
verses.text: For their sakes he was willing to live, for whose sakes he was prepared to die.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1025
verses.text: And that ye may know that it is this perfect charity which that man violates not, and against which that man sins not, who is born of God; this is what the Lord saith to Peter; "Peter lovest thou me?" And he answers, "I love".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1026
verses.text: He saith not, If thou love me, shew kindness to me.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1027
verses.text: For when the Lord was in mortal flesh, He hungered, He thirsted: at that time when He hungered and thirsted, He was taken in as a guest; those who had the means, ministered unto Him of their substance, as we read in the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1028
verses.text: Zacchaeus entertained Him as his guest: he was saved from his disease by entertaining the Physician.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1029
verses.text: From what disease? The disease of avarice.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1030
verses.text: For he was very rich, and the chief of the publicans.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1031
verses.text: Mark the man made whole from the disease of avarice: "The half of my goods I give to the poor; and if I have taken any thing from  any man, I will restore him fourfold".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1032
verses.text: That he kept the other half, was not to enjoy it, but to pay his debts.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1033
verses.text: Well, he at that time entertained the Physician as his guest, because there was infirmity of the flesh in the Lord, to which men might show this kindness; and this, because it was His will to grant this very thing to them that did Him kind service; for the benefit was to them that did the service, not to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1034
verses.text: For, could He to whom angels ministered require these men's kindness? Not even His servant Elias, to whom He sent bread and flesh by the ravens upon a certain occasion had need of this; and yet that a religious widow might be blessed, the servant of God is sent, and he whom God in secret did feed, is fed by the widow.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1035
verses.text: But still, although by the means of these servants of God, those who consider their need get good to themselves, in respect of that reward most manifestly set forth by the Lord in the Gospel: "He that receiveth a righteous man in the name of a righteous man shall receive a righteous man's reward: and he that receiveth a prophet in the name of a prophet shall receive a prophet's reward: and whosoever shall give to drink unto one of these little ones a cup of cold water only in the name of a disciple, verily I say unto you, He shall in no wise lose his reward:" although, then, they that do this, do it to their own good: yet neither could this kind office be done to Him when about to ascend into Heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1036
verses.text: What could Peter, who loved Him, render unto Him? Hear what.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1037
verses.text: "Feed my sheep:" i-e: do for the brethren, that which I have done for thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1038
verses.text: I redeemed all with my blood: hesitate not to die for confession of the truth, that the rest may imitate you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1040
verses.text: But this, as we have said, brethren, is perfect charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1041
verses.text: He that is born of God hath it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1042
verses.text: Mark, my beloved, see what I say.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1043
verses.text: Behold, a man has received the Sacrament of that birth, being baptized; he hath the Sacrament, and a great Sacrament, divine, holy, ineffable.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1044
verses.text: Consider what a Sacrament! To make him a new man by remission of all sins! Nevertheless, let him look well to the heart, whether that be thoroughly done there, which is done in the body; let him see whether he have charity, and then say, I am born of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1045
verses.text: If however he have it not, he has indeed the soldier's mark upon him, but he roams as a deserter.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1046
verses.text: Let him have charity; otherwise let him not say that he is born of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1047
verses.text: But he says, I have the Sacrament.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1048
verses.text: Hear the Apostle: "If I know all mysteries, and have all faith, so that I can remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1050
verses.text: This, if ye remember, we gave you to understand in beginning to read this Epistle, that nothing in it is so commended as charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1051
verses.text: Even if it seems to speak of various other things, to this it makes its way back, and whatever it says, it will needs bring all to bear upon charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1052
verses.text: Let us see whether it does so here.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1053
verses.text: Mark: "Whosoever is born of God doth not commit sin".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1054
verses.text: We ask, what sin? because if thou understand all sin, it will be contrary to that place, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1055
verses.text: Then let him say what sin; let him teach us; lest haply I may have rashly said that the sin here is the violation of charity, because he said above, "He that hateth his brother is in darkness, and walketh in darkness, and knoweth not whither he goeth, because the darkness hath blinded his eyes".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1056
verses.text: But perhaps he has said something in what comes afterwards, and has mentioned charity by name? See that this circuit of words hath this end, hath this issue.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1057
verses.text: "Whosoever is born of God, sinneth not, because His seed remaineth in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1058
verses.text: The "seed" of God, i-e: the word of God: whence the apostle saith, "I have begotten you through the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1059
verses.text: And he cannot sin, because he is born of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1060
verses.text: Let him tell us this, let us see in what we cannot sin.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1061
verses.text: "In this are manifested the children of God and the children of the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1062
verses.text: Whosoever is not righteous is not of God, neither he that loveth not his brother".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1063
verses.text: Aye, now indeed it is manifest of what he speaks: "Neither he that loveth not his brother".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1064
verses.text: Therefore, love alone puts the difference between the children of God and the children of the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1065
verses.text: Let them all sign themselves with the sign of the cross of Christ; let them all respond, Amen; let all sing Alleluia; let all be baptized, let all come to church, let all build the walls of churches: there is no discerning of the children of God from the children of the devil, but only by charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1066
verses.text: They that have charity are born of God: they that have it not, are not born of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1067
verses.text: A mighty token, a mighty distinction! Have what thou wilt; if this alone thou have not, it profiteth thee nothing: other things if thou have not, have this, and thou hast fulfilled the law.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1068
verses.text: "For he that loveth another hath fulfilled the law," saith the apostle: and, "Charity is the fulfilling of the law".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1069
verses.text: I take this to be the pearl which the merchant man in the Gospel is described to have been seeking, who  "found one pearl, and sold all that he had, and bought it".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1070
verses.text: This is the pearl of price, Charity, without which whatever thou mayest have, profiteth thee nothing: which if alone thou have, it sufficeth thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1071
verses.text: Now, with faith thou seest, then with actual beholding thou shalt see.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1072
verses.text: For if we love when we see not, how shall we embrace it when we see! But wherein must we exercise ourselves? In brotherly love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1073
verses.text: Thou mayest say to me, I have not seen God: canst thou say to me, I have not seen man? Love thy brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1074
verses.text: For if thou love thy brother whom thou seest, at the same time thou shalt see God also; because thou shalt see Charity itself, and within dwelleth God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1076
verses.text: "Whosoever is not righteous is not of God, neither he that loveth not his brother".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1077
verses.text: "For this is the message:" mark how he confirms it: "For this is the message which we heard from the beginning, that we should love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1078
verses.text: He has made it manifest to us that it is of this he speaks; whoso acts against this commandment, is in that accursed sin, into which those fall who are not born of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1079
verses.text: "Not as Cain, who was of that wicked one, and slew his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1080
verses.text: And wherefore slew he him? Because his own works were evil, and his brother's righteous".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1081
verses.text: Therefore, where envy is, brotherly love cannot be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1082
verses.text: Mark, my beloved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1083
verses.text: He that envieth, loveth not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1084
verses.text: The sin of the devil is in that man; because the devil through envy cast man down.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1085
verses.text: For he fell, and envied him that stood.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1086
verses.text: He did not wish to cast man down that he himself might stand, but only that he might not fall alone.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1087
verses.text: Hold fast in your mind from this that he has subjoined, that envy cannot exist in charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1088
verses.text: Thou hast it openly, when charity was praised, "Charity envieth not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1089
verses.text: There was no charity in Cain; and had there been no charity in Abel, God would not have accepted his sacrifice.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1090
verses.text: For when they had both offered, the one of the fruits of the earth, the other of the offspring of the flock; what think ye, brethren, that God slighted the fruits of the earth, and loved the offspring of the flock? God had not regard to the hands, but saw in the heart: and whom He saw offer with charity, to his sacrifice He had respect; whom He saw offer with envy, from his sacrifice He turned away His eyes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1091
verses.text: By the good works, then, of Abel, he means only charity: by the evil works of Cain he means only his hatred of his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1092
verses.text: It was not enough that he hated his brother and envied his good works; because he would not imitate, he would kill.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1093
verses.text: And hence it appeared that he was a child of the devil, and hence also that the other was God's righteous one.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1094
verses.text: Hence then are men discerned, my brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1095
verses.text: Let no man mark the tongue, but the deeds and the heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1096
verses.text: If any do not good for his brethren, he shews what he has in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1097
verses.text: By temptations are men proved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1099
verses.text: "Marvel not, brethren, if the world hate us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1100
verses.text: Must one often be telling you what "the world" means? Not the heaven, not the earth, nor these visible works which God made; but lovers of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1101
verses.text: By often saying these things, to some I am burdensome: but I am so far from saying it without a cause, that some may be questioned whether I said it, and they cannot answer.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1102
verses.text: Let then, even by thrusting it upon them, something stick fast in the hearts of them that hear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1103
verses.text: What is "the world"? The world, when put in a bad sense, is, lovers of the world: the world, when the word is used in praise, is heaven and earth, and the works of God that are in them; whence it is said, "And the world was made by Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1104
verses.text: Also, the world is the fullness of the earth, as John himself hath said, "Not only for our sins is He the propitiator, but (for the sins) of the whole world:" he means, "of the world," of all the faithful scattered throughout the whole earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1105
verses.text: But the world in a bad sense, is, lovers of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1106
verses.text: They that love the world, cannot love their brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1108
verses.text: "If the world hate us: we know"â€”What do we know?â€”"that we have passed from death unto life"â€”How do we know? "Because we love the brethren".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1109
verses.text: Let none ask man: let each return to his own heart: if he find there brotherly love, let him set his mind at rest, because he is "passed from death unto life".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1110
verses.text: Already he is on the right hand: let him not regard that at present his glory is hidden: when the Lord shall come, then shall he appear in glory.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1111
verses.text: For he has life in him, but as yet in winter; the root is alive, but the branches, so to say, are dry: within is the substance that has the life in it, within are the leaves of trees, within are the fruits: but they wait for the summer.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1112
verses.text: Well then, "we know that we have passed from death unto life, because we love the brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1113
verses.text: He that loveth not, abideth in death".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1114
verses.text: Lest ye should think it a light matter, brethren, to hate, or, not to love, hear what follows: "Every one that hateth his brother, is a murderer".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1115
verses.text: How now, if any made light of hating his brother, will he also in his heart make light of murder? He does not stir his hands to kill a man; yet he is already held  by God a murderer; the other lives, and yet this man is already judged as his slayer! "Every one that hateth his brother is a murderer: and ye know that no murderer hath eternal life abiding in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1117
verses.text: "In this know we love:" he means, perfection of love, that perfection which we have bidden you lay to heart: "In this know we love, that He laid down His life for us: and we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1118
verses.text: Lo here, whence that came: "Peter, lovest thou me? Feed My sheep".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1119
verses.text: For, that ye may know that He would have His sheep to be so fed by him, as that he should lay down his life for the sheep, straightway said He this to him: "When thou wast young, thou girdedst thyself, and walkedst whither thou wouldest: but when thou shalt be old, thou shalt stretch forth thy hands, and another shall gird thee, and carry thee whither thou wouldest not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1120
verses.text: This spake He," saith the evangelist, "signifying by what death he should glorify God;" so that to whom He had said, Feed my sheep," the same He might teach to lay down his life for His sheep.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1122
verses.text: Whence beginneth charity, brethren? Attend a little: to what it is perfected, ye have heard; the very end of it, and the very measure of it is what the Lord hath put before us in the Gospel: "Greater love hath no man," saith He, "than that one lay down his life for his friends".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1123
verses.text: Its perfection, therefore, He hath put before us in the Gospel, and here also it is its perfection that is put before us: but ye ask yourselves, and say to yourselves, When shall it be possible for us to have "this" charity? Do not too soon despair of thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1124
verses.text: Haply, it is born and is not yet perfect; nourish it, that it be not choked.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1125
verses.text: But thou wilt say to me, And by what am I to know it? For to what it is perfected, we have heard; whence it begins, let us hear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1126
verses.text: He goes on to say: "But whoso hath this world's good, and seeth his brother have hunger, and shutteth up his bowels of compassion from him, how can the love of God dwell in him?" Lo, whence charity begins withal! If thou art not yet equal to the dying for thy brother, be thou even now equal to the giving of thy means to thy brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1127
verses.text: Even now let charity smite thy bowels, that not of vainglory thou shouldest do it, but of the innermost marrow of mercy; that thou consider him, now in want.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1128
verses.text: For if thy superfluities thou canst not give to thy brother, canst thou lay down thy life for thy brother? There lies thy money in thy bosom, which thieves may take from thee; and though thieves do not take it, by dying thou wilt leave it, even if it leave not thee while living: what wilt thou do with it? Thy brother hungers, he is in necessity: belike he is in suspense, is distressed by his creditor: he is thy brother, alike ye are bought, one is the price paid for you, ye are both redeemed by the blood of Christ: see whether thou have mercy, if thou have this world's means.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1129
verses.text: Perchance thou sayest, "What concerns it me? Am I to give my money, that he may not suffer trouble?" If this be the answer thy heart makes to thee, the love of the Father abideth not in thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1130
verses.text: If the love of the Father abide not in thee, thou art not born of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1131
verses.text: How boastest thou to be a Christian? Thou hast the name, and hast not the deeds.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1132
verses.text: But if the work shall follow the name, let any call thee pagan, show thou by deeds that thou art a Christian.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1133
verses.text: For if by deeds thou dost not show thyself a Christian, all men may call thee a Christian yet; what doth the name profit thee where the thing is not forthcoming? "But whoso hath this world's good, and seeth his brother have need, and shutteth up his bowels of compassion from him, how can the love of God dwell in him?" And then he goes on: "My little children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue but in deed and in truth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1135
verses.text: I suppose the thing is now made manifest to you my brethren: this great and most concerning secret and mystery.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1136
verses.text: What is the force of charity, all Scripture doth set forth; but I know not whether any where it be more largely set forth than in this Epistle.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1137
verses.text: We pray you and beseech you in the Lord, that both what ye have heard ye will keep in  memory, and to that which is yet to be said, until the epistle be finished, will come with earnestness, and with earnestness hear the same.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1138
verses.text: But open ye your heart for the good seed: root out the thorns, that that which we are sowing in you be not choked, but rather that the harvest may grow, and that the Husbandman may rejoice and make ready the barn for you as for grain, not the fire as for the chaff.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1139
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1140
verses.text: 1 John III.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1142
verses.text: 3  "And herein we know that we are of the truth, and assure our hearts before Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1143
verses.text: For if our heart think ill of us, God is greater than our heart, and knoweth all things.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1144
verses.text: Beloved, if our heart think not ill of us, then have we confidence toward God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1145
verses.text: And whatsoever we ask, we shall receive of Him, because we keep His commandments, and do in His sight those things that please Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1146
verses.text: And this is His commandment, That we should believe on the name of His Son Jesus Christ, and love one another, as He gave us commandment.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1147
verses.text: And he that keepeth His commandments shall dwell in Him, and He in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1148
verses.text: And herein we know that He abideth in us, by the Holy Spirit which He hath given us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1149
verses.text: Dearly beloved, believe not every spirit, but try the spirits whether they are of God: because many false prophets are gone out into this world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1150
verses.text: In this is known the Spirit of God: every spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is of God: and every spirit that confesseth not that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is not of God: and this is the antichrist, of whom ye have heard that he should come; and even now already is he in this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1152
verses.text: If ye remember, brethren, yesterday we closed our sermon at this sentence, which without doubt behooved and does behoove to abide in your heart, seeing it was the last ye heard.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1153
verses.text: "My little children, let us not love only in word and in tongue; but in deed and in truth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1154
verses.text: Then he goes on: "And herein we know that we are of the truth, and assure our hearts before Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1155
verses.text: "For if our heart think ill of us, God is greater than our heart, and knoweth all things".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1156
verses.text: He had said, "Let us not love only in word and in tongue, but in work and in truth:" we are asked, In what work, or in what truth, is he known that loveth God, or loveth his brother? Above he had said up to what point charity is perfected: what the Lord saith in the Gospel, "Greater love than this hath no man, that one lay down his life for his friends," this same had the apostle also said: "As He laid down His life for us, we ought also to lay down our lives for the brethren".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1157
verses.text: This is the perfection of charity, and greater can not at all be found.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1158
verses.text: But because it is not perfect in all, and that man ought not to despair in whom it is not perfect, if that be already born which may be perfected: and of course if born, it must be nourished, and by certain nourishments of its own must be brought unto its proper perfection: therefore, we have asked concerning the commencement of charity, where it begins, and there have straightway found: "But whoso hath this world's goods, and seeth his brother have need, and shutteth up his bowels of compassion from him, how dwelleth the love of the Father in him?" Here then hath this charity, my brethren, its beginning: to give of one's superfluities to him that hath need to him that is in any distress; of one's temporal abundance to deliver his brother from temporal tribulation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1159
verses.text: Here is the first rise of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1160
verses.text: This, being thus begun, if thou shalt nourish with the word of God and hope of the life to come, thou wilt come at last unto that perfection, that thou shalt be ready to lay down thy life for thy brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1162
verses.text: But, because many such things are done by men who seek other objects, and who love not the brethren; let us come back to the tes  timony of conscience.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1163
verses.text: How do we prove that many such things are done by men who love not the brethren? How many in heresies and schisms call themselves martyrs! They seem to themselves to lay down their lives for their brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1164
verses.text: If for the brethren they laid down their lives, they would not separate themselves from the whole brotherhood.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1165
verses.text: Again, how many there are who for the sake of vainglory bestow much, give much, and seek therein but the praise of men and popular glory, which is full of windiness, and possesses no stability! Seeing, then, there are such, where shall be the proof of brotherly charity? Seeing he wished it to be proved, and hath said by way of admonition, "My little children, let us not love only in word and in tongue; but in deed and in truth;" we ask, in what work, in what truth? Can there be a more manifest work than to give to the poor? Many do this of vainglory, not of love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1166
verses.text: Can there be a greater work than to die for the brethren? This also, many would fain be thought to do, who do it of vainglory to get a name, not from bowels of love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1167
verses.text: It remains, that that man loves his brother, who before God, where God alone seeth, assures his own heart, and questions his heart whether he does this indeed for love of the brethren; and his witness is that eye which penetrates the heart, where man cannot look.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1168
verses.text: Therefore Paul the Apostle, because he was ready to die for the brethren, and said, "I will myself be spent for your souls," yet, because God only saw this in his heart, not the mortal men to whom he spake, he saith to them, "But to me it is a very small thing that I should be judged of you or at man's bar".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1169
verses.text: And the same apostle shows also in a certain place, that these things are oft done of empty vainglory, not upon the solid ground of love: for speaking of the praises of charity he saith, "If I distribute all my goods to the poor, and if I deliver up my body to be burned, but have not charity, it profiteth me nothing".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1170
verses.text: Is it possible for a man to do this without charity? It is.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1171
verses.text: For they that have divided unity, are persons that have not charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1172
verses.text: Seek there, and ye shall see many giving much to the poor; shall see others prepared to welcome death, insomuch that where there is no persecutor they cast themselves headlong: these doubtless without charity do this.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1173
verses.text: Let us come back then to conscience, of which the apostle saith: "For our glorying is this, the testimony of our conscience".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1174
verses.text: Let us come back to conscience, of which the same saith, "But let each prove his own work, and then he shall have glorying in himself and not in another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1175
verses.text: Therefore, let each one of us "prove his own work," whether it flow forth from the vein of charity, whether it be from charity as the root that his good works sprout forth as branches.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1176
verses.text: "But let each prove his own work, and then he shall have glorying in himself and not in another," not when another's tongue bears witness to him, but when his own conscience bears it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1178
verses.text: This it is then that he enforces here.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1179
verses.text: "In this we know that we are of the truth, when in deed and in truth" we love, "not only in words and in tongue: and assure our heart before Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1180
verses.text: What meaneth, "before Him?" Where He seeth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1181
verses.text: Whence the Lord Himself in the Gospel saith: "Take heed that ye do not your righteousness before men, to be seen of them: otherwise ye have no reward with your Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1182
verses.text: And what meaneth, "Let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth:" except that the right hand means a pure conscience, the left hand the lust of the world? Many through lust of the world do many wonderful things: the left hand worketh, not the right.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1183
verses.text: The right hand ought to work, and without knowledge of the left hand, so that lust of the world may not even mix itself therewith when by love we work aught that is good.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1184
verses.text: And where do we get to know this? Thou art before God: question thine heart, see what thou hast done, and what therein was thine aim; thy salvation, or the windy praise of men.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1185
verses.text: Look within, for man cannot judge whom he cannot see.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1186
verses.text: If "we assure our heart," let it be "before Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1187
verses.text: Because "if our heart think ill of us," i-e: accuse us within, that we do not the thing with that mind it ought to be done withal, "greater is God than our heart, and knoweth all things".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1188
verses.text: Thou hidest thine heart from man: hide it from God if thou canst! How shalt thou hide it from Him, to whom it is said by a sinner, fearing and confessing, "Whither shall I go from Thy Spirit? and from Thy face whither shall I flee?" He sought a way to flee, to escape the judgment of God, and found none.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1189
verses.text: For where is God not? "If I shall ascend," saith he, "into heaven, Thou art there: if I shall descend  into hell, Thou art there".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1190
verses.text: Whither wilt thou go? whither wilt thou flee? Wilt thou hear counsel? If thou wouldest flee from Him, flee to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1191
verses.text: Flee to Him by confessing, not from Him by hiding: hide thou canst not, but confess thou canst.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1192
verses.text: Say unto Him, "Thou art my place to flee unto;" and let love be nourished in thee, which alone leadeth unto life.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1193
verses.text: Let thy conscience bear thee witness that thy love is of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1194
verses.text: If it be of God, do not wish to display it before men; because neither men's praises lift thee unto heaven, nor their censures put thee down from thence.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1195
verses.text: Let Him see, who crowneth thee: be He thy witness, by whom as judge thou art crowned.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1196
verses.text: "Greater is God than our heart, and knoweth all things".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1198
verses.text: "Beloved, if our heart think not ill of us, we have confidence towards God:"â€”What meaneth, "If our heart think not ill"? If it make true answer to us, that we love and that there is genuine love in us: not feigned but sincere; seeking a brother's salvation, expecting no emolument from a brother, but only his salvationâ€”"we have confidence toward God: and whatsoever we ask, we shall receive of Him, because we keep His commandments".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1199
verses.text: â€”Therefore, not in the sight of men, but where God Himself seeth, in the heartâ€”"we have confidence," then, "towards God: and whatsoever we ask, we shall receive of Him:" howbeit, because we keep His commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1200
verses.text: What are "His commandments"? Must we be always repeating? "A new commandment give I unto you, that ye love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1201
verses.text: It is charity itself that he speaks of, it is this that he enforces.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1202
verses.text: Whoso then shall have brotherly charity, and have it before God, where God seeth, and his heart being interrogated under righteous examination make him none other answer than that the genuine root of charity is there for good fruits to come from; that man hath confidence with God, and whatsoever he shall ask, he shall receive of Him, because he keepeth His commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1204
verses.text: Here a question meets us: for it is not this or that man, or thou or I that come in question,â€”for if I have asked any thing of God and receive it not, any person may easily say of me, "He hath not charity:" and of any man soever of this present time, this may easily be said; and let any think what he will, a man of man:â€”not we, but those come more in question, those men of whom it is on all hands known that they were saints when they wrote, and that they are now with God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1205
verses.text: Where is the man that hath charity, if Paul had it not, who said, "Our mouth is open unto you, O ye Corinthians, our heart is enlarged; ye are not straitened in us:" who said, "I will myself be spent for your souls:" and so great grace was in him, that it was manifested that he had charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1206
verses.text: And yet we find that he asked and did not receive.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1207
verses.text: What say we, brethren? It is a question: look attentively to God: it is a great question, this also.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1208
verses.text: Just as, where it was said of sin, "He that is born of God sinneth not:" we found this sin to be the violating of charity, and that this was the thing strictly intended in that place: so too we ask now what it is that he would say.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1209
verses.text: For if thou look but to the words, it seems plain: if thou take the examples into the account, it is obscure.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1210
verses.text: Than the words here nothing can be plainer.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1211
verses.text: "And whatsoever we ask, we shall receive of Him, because we keep His commandments, and do those things that are pleasing in His sight".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1212
verses.text: "Whatsoever we ask," saith he, "we shall receive of Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1213
verses.text: He hath put us sorely to straits.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1214
verses.text: In the other place also he would put us to straits, if he meant all sin: but then we found room to expound it in this, that he meant it of a certain sin, not of all sin; howbeit of a sin which "whosoever is born of God committeth not:" and we found that this same sin is none other than the violation of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1215
verses.text: We have also a manifest example from the Gospel, when the Lord saith, "If I had not come, they had not had sin".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1216
verses.text: How? Were the Jews innocent when He came to them, because He so speaks? Then if He had not come, would they have had no sin? Then did the Physician's presence make one sick, not take away the fever? What madman even would say this? He came not but to cure and heal the sick.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1217
verses.text: Therefore when He said, "If I had not come, they had not had sin," what would He have to be understood, but a certain sin in particular? For there was a sin which the Jews would not have had.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1218
verses.text: What sin? That they believed not on Him, that when he had come they despised Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1219
verses.text: As then He there said "sin," and it does not follow that we are to understand all sin, but a certain sin: so here also not all sin, lest it be contrary to that place where he saith, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us:" but a certain sin in particular, that is, the violation of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1220
verses.text: But in this place he hath bound us more tightly: "If we shall ask," he hath said, "if our heart accuse us not, and tell us in answer, in the sight of God, that true love is in us;" "Whatsoever we ask, we shall receive of Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1222
verses.text: Well now: I have already told you, my, beloved brethren, let no man turn toward us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1223
verses.text: For what are we? or what are ye? What, but the Church of God which is known to all? And, if it please Him, in that Church are we; and those of us who by love abide in it, there let us persevere, if we would show the love we have.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1224
verses.text: But then the apostle Paul, what evil are we to think of him? He not love the brethren! He not have within himself the testimony of his conscience in the sight of God! Paul not have within him that root of charity whence all good fruits proceeded! What madman would say this? Well then: where find we that the apostle asked and did not receive? He saith himself: "Lest I should be exalted above measure through the abundance of the revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, an angel of Satan to buffet me.
