verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1225
verses.text: For which thing I besought the Lord thrice, that He would take it from me.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1226
verses.text: And He said unto me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1227
verses.text: Lo, he was not heard in his prayer that the "angel of Satan" should be taken from him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1228
verses.text: But wherefore? Because it was not good for him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1229
verses.text: He was heard, then, for salvation, when he was not heard according to his wish.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1230
verses.text: Know, my beloved, a great mystery: which we urge upon your consideration on purpose that it may not slip from you in your temptations.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1231
verses.text: The saints are in all things heard unto salvation: they are always heard in that which respects their eternal salvation; it is this that they desire: because in regard of this, their prayers are always heard.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1233
verses.text: But let us distinguish God's different ways of hearing prayer.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1234
verses.text: For we find some not heard for their wish, heard for salvation: and again some we find heard for their wish, not heard for salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1235
verses.text: Mark this difference, hold fast this example of a man not heard for his wish but heard for salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1236
verses.text: Hear the apostle Paul; for what is the hearing of prayer unto salvation, God Himself showed him: "Sufficient for thee," saith He, "is my grace; for strength is perfected in weakness".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1237
verses.text: Thou hast besought, hast cried, hast thrice cried: the very cry thou didst raise once for all I heard, I turned not away mine ears from thee; I know what I should do: thou wouldest have it taken away, the healing thing by which thou art burned; I know the infirmity by which thou art burdened.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1238
verses.text: Well then: here is a man who was heard for salvation, while as to his will he was not heard.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1239
verses.text: Where find we persons heard for their will, not heard for salvation? Do we find, think we, some wicked, some impious man, heard of God for his will, not heard for salvation? If I put to you the instance of some man, perchance thou wilt say to me, "It is thou that callest him wicked, for he was righteous; had he not been righteous, his prayer would not have been heard by God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1240
verses.text: The instance I am about to allege is of one, of whose iniquity and impiety none can doubt.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1241
verses.text: The devil himself: he asked for Job, and received.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1242
verses.text: Have ye not here also heard concerning the devil, that "he that committeth sin is of the devil"? Not that the devil created, but that the sinner imitates.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1243
verses.text: Is it not said of him, "He stood not in the truth"? Is not even he "that old serpent," who, through the woman pledged the first man in the drink of poison? Who even in the case of Job, kept for him his wife, that by her the husband might be, not comforted, but tempted? The devil asked for a holy man, to tempt him; and he received: the apostle asked that the thorn in the flesh might be taken from him, and he received not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1244
verses.text: But the apostle was more heard than the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1245
verses.text: For the apostle was heard for salvation, though not for his wish: the devil was heard for his wish, but for damnation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1246
verses.text: For that Job was yielded up to him to be tempted, was in order that by his standing the proof the devil should be tormented.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1247
verses.text: But this, my brethren, we find not only in the Old Testament books, but also in the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1248
verses.text: The demons besought the Lord, when He expelled them from the man, that they might be permitted to go into the swine.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1249
verses.text: Should the Lord not have power to tell them not to approach even those creatures? For, had it not been His will to permit this, they were not about to rebel against the King of heaven and earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1250
verses.text: But with a view to a certain mystery, with a certain ulterior meaning, He let the demons go into the swine: to show that the devil hath dominion in them that lead the life of swine.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1251
verses.text: Demons then were heard in their request; was the apostle not heard? Or rather (what is truer) shall we say, The apostle was heard, the demons not heard? Their will was effected; his weal was perfected.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1253
verses.text: Agreeably with this, we ought to understand that God, though He give not to our will, doth give for our salvation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1254
verses.text: For sup  pose the thing thou have asked be to thine hurt, and the Physician knows that it is to thine hurt; what then? It is not to be said that the physician does not give ear to thee, when, perhaps, thou askest for cold water, and if it is good for thee, he gives it immediately, if not good, he gives it not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1255
verses.text: Had he no ears for thy request, or rather, did he give ear for thy weal, even when he gainsaid thy will? Then let there be in you charity, my brethren; let it be in you, and then set your minds at rest: even when the thing ye ask for is not given you, your prayer is granted, only, ye know it not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1256
verses.text: Many have been given into their own hands, to their own hurt: of whom the apostle saith, "God gave them up to their own hearts' lusts".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1257
verses.text: Some man hath asked for a great sum of money; he hath received, to his hurt.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1258
verses.text: When he had it not, he had little to fear; no sooner did he come to have it, than he became a prey to the more powerful.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1259
verses.text: Was not that man's request granted to his own hurt, who would needs have that for which he should be sought after by the robber, whereas, being poor, none sought after him? Learn to beseech God that ye may commit it to the Physician to do what He knows best.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1260
verses.text: Do thou confess the disease, let Him apply the means of healing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1261
verses.text: Do thou only hold fast charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1262
verses.text: For He will needs cut, will needs burn; what if thou criest out, and art not spared for thy crying under the cutting, under the burning and the tribulation, yet He knows how far the rottenness reaches.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1263
verses.text: Thou wouldest have Him even now take off His hands, and He considers only the deepness of the sore; He knows how far to go.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1264
verses.text: He does not attend to thee for thy will, but he does attend to thee for thy healing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1265
verses.text: Be ye sure, then, my brethren, that what the apostle saith is true: "For we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered: for He maketh intercession for the saints".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1266
verses.text: How is it said, "The Spirit itself intercedeth for the saints," but as meaning the charity which is wrought in thee by the Spirit? For therefore saith the same apostle: "The charity of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given unto us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1267
verses.text: It is charity that groans, it is charity that prays: against it He who gave it cannot shut His ears.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1268
verses.text: Set your minds at rest: let charity ask, and the ears of God are there.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1269
verses.text: Not that which thou wishest is done, but that is done which is advantageous.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1270
verses.text: Therefore, "whatever we ask," saith he, "we shall receive of Him," I have already said, If thou understand it to mean, "for salvation," there is no question: if not for salvation, there is a question, and a great one, a question that makes thee an accuser of the apostle Paul.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1271
verses.text: "Whatever we ask, we receive of Him, because we keep His commandments, and do these things that are pleasing in His sight:" within, where He seeth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1273
verses.text: And what are those commandments? "This," saith he, "is His commandment, That we should believe on the name of His Son Jesus Christ, and love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1274
verses.text: Ye see that this is the commandment: ye see that whoso doeth aught against this commandment, doeth the sin from which "every one that is born of God" is free.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1275
verses.text: "As He gave us commandment:" that we love one another.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1276
verses.text: "And he that keepeth His commandment"â€”ye see that none other thing is bidden us than that we love one anotherâ€”"And he that keepeth His commandment shall abide in Him, and He in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1277
verses.text: "And in this we know that He abideth in us, by the Spirit which He hath given us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1278
verses.text: Is it not manifest that this is what the Holy Ghost works in man, that there should be in him love and charity? Is it not manifest, as the Apostle Paul saith, that "the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given us"? For [our apostle] was speaking of charity, and was saying that we ought in the sight of God to interrogate our own heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1279
verses.text: "But if our heart think not ill of us:" i-e: if it confess that from the love of our brother is done in us whatever is done in any good work.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1280
verses.text: And then besides, in speaking of the commandment, he says this: "This is His commandment, That we should believe on the name of His Son Jesus Christ, and love one another, as He gave us commandment".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1281
verses.text: "And he that doeth His commandment abideth in Him, and He in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1282
verses.text: In this we know that He abideth in us, by the Spirit which He hath given us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1283
verses.text: If in truth thou find that thou hast charity, thou hast the Spirit of God in order to understand: for a very necessary thing it is.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1285
verses.text: In the earliest times, "the Holy Ghost fell upon them that believed: and they spake with tongues," which they had not learned, "as the Spirit gave them utterance".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1286
verses.text: These were signs adapted to the time.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1287
verses.text: For there behooved to be that betokening of the Holy Spirit in all tongues, to shew that the Gospel of God was to run through all tongues over  the whole earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1288
verses.text: That thing was done for a betokening, and it passed away.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1289
verses.text: In the laying on of hands now, that persons may receive the Holy Ghost, do we look that they should speak with tongues? Or when we laid the hand on these infants,  did each one of you look to see whether they would speak with tongues, and, when he saw that they did not speak with tongues, was any of you so wrong-minded as to say, These have not received the Holy Ghost; for, had they received, they would speak with tongues as was the case in those times? If then the witness of the presence of the Holy Ghost be not now given through these miracles, by what is it given, by what does one get to know that he has received the Holy Ghost? Let him question his own heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1290
verses.text: If he love his brother the Spirit of God dwelleth in him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1291
verses.text: Let him see, let him prove himself before the eyes of God, let him see whether there be in him the love of peace and unity, the love of the Church that is spread over the whole earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1292
verses.text: Let him not rest only in his loving the brother whom he has before his eyes, for we have many brethren whom we do not see, and in the unity of the Spirit we are joined to them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1293
verses.text: What marvel that they are not with us? We are in one body, we have one Head, in heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1294
verses.text: Brethren, our two eyes do not see each other; as one may say, they do not know each other.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1295
verses.text: But in the charity of the bodily frame do they not know each other? For, to shew you that in the charity which knits them together they do know each other; when both eyes are open, the right may not rest on some object, on which the left shall not rest likewise.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1296
verses.text: Direct the glance of the right eye without the other, if thou canst.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1297
verses.text: Together they meet in one object, together they are directed to one object: their aim is one, their places diverse.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1298
verses.text: If then all who with thee love God have one aim with thee, heed not that in the body thou are separated in place; the eyesight of the heart ye have alike fixed on the light of truth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1299
verses.text: Then if thou wouldest know that thou hast received the Spirit, question thine heart: lest haply thou have the sacrament, and have not the virtue of the sacrament.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1300
verses.text: Question thine heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1301
verses.text: If love of thy brethren be there, set thy mind at rest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1302
verses.text: There cannot be love without the Spirit of God: since Paul cries, "The love of God is shed abroad in your hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given unto us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1304
verses.text: "Beloved, believe not every spirit".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1305
verses.text: Because he had said, "In this we know that He abideth in us, by the Spirit which He hath given us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1306
verses.text: But how this same Spirit is known, mark this: "Beloved, believe not every spirit, but prove the spirits whether they be from God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1307
verses.text: And who is he that proves the spirits? A hard matter has he put to us, my brethren! It is well for us that he should tell us himself how we are to discern them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1308
verses.text: He is about to tell us: fear not: but first see; mark: see that hereby is expressed the very thing that vain heretics taunt us withal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1309
verses.text: Mark, see what he says, "Beloved, believe not every spirit, but prove the spirits whether they be from God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1310
verses.text: The Holy Spirit is spoken of in the Gospel by the name of water; where the Lord "cried and said, If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1311
verses.text: He that believeth on me, out of his belly shall flow rivers of living water".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1312
verses.text: But the evangelist has expounded of what He said this: for he goes on to say, "But this spake He of the Spirit, which they that believed on Him should receive".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1313
verses.text: Wherefore did not the Lord baptize many? But what saith he? "For the Holy Ghost was not yet given; because that Jesus was not yet glorified".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1314
verses.text: Then seeing those had baptism, and had not yet received the Holy Ghost, whom on the day of Pentecost the Lord sent from heaven, the glorifying of the Lord was first waited for, so that the Spirit might be given.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1315
verses.text: Even before He was glorified, and before He sent the Spirit, He yet invited men to prepare themselves for the receiving of the water of which He said, "Whoso thirsteth, let him come and drink;" and, "He that believeth on me, out of his belly shall flow rivers of living water".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1316
verses.text: What meaneth, "Rivers of living water"? What is that water? Let no man ask me; ask the Gospel.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1317
verses.text: "But this," saith it, "He said of the Spirit, which they should receive that should believe on Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1318
verses.text: Consequently, the water of the sacrament is one thing: another, the water which betokens the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1319
verses.text: The water of the sacrament is visible: the water of the Spirit invisible.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1320
verses.text: That washes the body, and betokens that which is done in the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1321
verses.text: By this Spirit the soul itself is cleansed and fed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1322
verses.text: This is the Spirit of God, which heretics and all that cut themselves off from the Church, cannot have.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1323
verses.text: And whosoever do not openly cut themselves off, but by iniquity are cut off, and being within, whirl about as chaff and are not grain; these have not this Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1324
verses.text: This Spirit is denoted by the Lord under the name of water: and we have heard from this epistle, "Believe not every spirit;" and those words of Solomon  bear witness, "From strange water keep thee far".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1325
verses.text: What meaneth, "water"? Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1326
verses.text: Does water always signify spirit? Not always: but in some places it signifies the Spirit, in some places it signifies baptism, in some places signifies peoples, in some places signifies counsel: thus thou findest it said in a certain place, "Counsel is a fountain of life to them that possess it".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1327
verses.text: So then, in divers places of the Scriptures, the term "water" signifies divers things.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1328
verses.text: Now however by the term water ye have heard the Holy Spirit spoken of, not by an interpretation of ours but by witness of the Gospel, where it saith, "But this said He of the Spirit, which they should receive that should believe on Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1329
verses.text: If then by the name of water is signified the Holy Spirit, and this epistle saith to us, "Believe not every spirit, but prove the spirits, whether they be of God;" let us understand that of this it is said, "From strange water keep thee far, and from a strange fountain drink thou not".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1330
verses.text: What meaneth, "From a strange fountain drink thou not"? A strange spirit believe thou not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1332
verses.text: There remains then the test by which it is to be proved to be the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1333
verses.text: He has indeed set down a sign, and this, belike, difficult: let us see, however.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1334
verses.text: We are to recur to that charity; it is that which teacheth us, because it is the unction.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1335
verses.text: However, what saith he here? "Prove the spirits, whether they be from God: because many false prophets have gone out into this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1336
verses.text: Now there are all heretics and all schismatics.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1337
verses.text: How then am I to prove the spirit? He goes on: "In this is known the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1338
verses.text: Wake up the ears of your heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1339
verses.text: We were at a loss; we were saying, Who knows? who discerns? Behold, he is about to tell the sign.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1340
verses.text: "Hereby is known the Spirit of God: every spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is of God: and every spirit that confesseth not that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is not of God: and this is the antichrist, of whom ye have heard that he should come; and even now already is he in this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1341
verses.text: Our ears, so to say, are on the alert for discerning of the spirits; and we have been told something, such that thereby we discern not a whit the more.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1342
verses.text: For what saith he? "Every spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ came in the flesh, is of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1343
verses.text: Then is the spirit that is among the heretics, of God, seeing they "confess that Jesus Christ came in the flesh"? Aye, here perchance they lift themselves up against us, and say: Ye have not the Spirit from God; but we confess "that Jesus Christ came in the flesh:" but the apostle here hath said that those have not the Spirit of God, who confess not "that Jesus Christ came in the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1344
verses.text: Ask the Arians: they confess "that Jesus Christ came in the flesh:" ask the Eunomians; they confess "that Jesus Christ came in the flesh:" ask the Macedonians; they confess "that Jesus Christ came in the flesh:" put the question to the Cataphryges; they confess "that Jesus Christ came in the flesh:" put it to the Novatians; they confess "that Jesus Christ came in the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1345
verses.text: Then have all these heresies the Spirit of God? Are they then no false prophets? Is there then no deception there, no seduction there? Assuredly they are antichrists; for "they went out from us, but were not of us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1347
verses.text: What are we to do then? By what to discern them? Be very attentive; let us go together in heart, and knock.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1348
verses.text: Charity herself keeps watch; for it is none other than she that shall knock, she also that shall open: anon ye shall understand in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1349
verses.text: Already ye have heard that it was said above, "Whoso denieth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, the same is an antichrist".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1350
verses.text: There also we asked, Who denies? because neither do we deny, nor do those deny.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1351
verses.text: And we found that some do in their deeds deny; and we brought testimony from the apostle, who saith, "For they confess that they know God, but in their deeds deny Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1352
verses.text: Thus then let us now also make the enquiry in the deeds not in the tongue.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1353
verses.text: What is the spirit that is not from God? That "which denieth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1354
verses.text: And what is the spirit that is from God? That "which confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1355
verses.text: Who is he that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh? Now, brethren, to the mark! let us look to the works, not stop at the noise of the tongue.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1356
verses.text: Let us ask why Christ came in the flesh, so we get at the persons who deny that He is come in the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1357
verses.text: If thou stop at tongues, why, thou shalt hear many a heresy confessing that Christ is come in the flesh: but the truth convicteth those men.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1358
verses.text: Wherefore came Christ in the flesh? Was He not God? Is it not written of Him, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God?" Was it not He that did feed angels, is it not He that doth feed  angels? Did He not in such sort come hither, that He departed not thence? Did He not in such sort ascend, that He forsook not us? Wherefore then came He in the flesh? Because it behooved us to have the hope of resurrection shown unto us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1359
verses.text: God He was, and in flesh He came; for God could not die, flesh could die; He came then in the flesh, that He might die for us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1360
verses.text: But how died He for us? "Greater charity than this hath no man, that a man lay down his life for his friends".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1361
verses.text: Charity therefore brought Him to the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1362
verses.text: Whoever therefore has not charity denies that Christ is come in the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1363
verses.text: Here then do thou now question all heretics.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1364
verses.text: Did Christ come in the flesh? "He did come; this I believe, this I confess".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1365
verses.text: Nay, this thou deniest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1366
verses.text: "How do I deny? Thou hearest that I say it!" Nay, I convict thee of denying it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1367
verses.text: Thou sayest with the voice, deniest with the heart; sayest in words, deniest in deeds.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1368
verses.text: "How," sayest thou, "do I deny in deeds?" Because the end for which Christ came in the flesh, was, that He might die for us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1369
verses.text: He died for us, because therein He taught much charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1370
verses.text: "Greater charity than this hath no man, that a man lay down his life for his friends".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1371
verses.text: Thou hast not charity, seeing thou for thine own honor dividest unity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1372
verses.text: Therefore by this understand ye the spirit that is from God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1373
verses.text: Give the earthen vessels a tap, put them to the proof, whether haply they be cracked and give a dull sound: see whether they ring full and clear, see whether charity be there.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1374
verses.text: Thou takest thyself away from the unity of the whole earth, thou dividest the Church by schisms, thou rendest the Body of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1375
verses.text: He came in the flesh, to gather in one, thou makest an outcry to scatter abroad.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1376
verses.text: This then is the Spirit of God, which saith that Jesus is come in the flesh, which saith, not in tongue but in deeds, which saith, not by making a noise but by loving.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1377
verses.text: And that spirit is not of God, which denies that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh; denies, here also, not in tongue but in life; not in words but in deeds.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1378
verses.text: It is manifest therefore by what we may know the brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1379
verses.text: Many within are in a sort within; but none without except he be indeed without.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1381
verses.text: Nay, and that ye may know that he has referred the matter to deeds, he saith, "And every spirit, qui solvit Christum, which does away with Christ that He came in the flesh, is not of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1382
verses.text: A doing away in deeds is meant.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1383
verses.text: What has he shown thee? "That denieth:" in that he saith, "doeth away" (or, "unmaketh").

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1384
verses.text: He came to gather in one, thou comest to unmake.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1385
verses.text: Thou wouldest pull Christ's members asunder.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1386
verses.text: How can it be said that thou deniest not that Christ is come in the flesh, who rendest assunder the Church of God which He hath gathered together? Therefore thou goest against Christ; thou art an antichrist.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1387
verses.text: Be thou within, or be thou without, thou art an antichrist: only, when thou art within, thou art hidden; when thou art without, thou art made manifest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1388
verses.text: Thou unmakest Jesus and deniest that He came in the flesh; thou art not of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1389
verses.text: Therefore He saith in the Gospel: "Whoso shall break one of these least commandments, and shall teach so, shall be called least in the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1390
verses.text: What is this breaking? What this teaching? A breaking in the deeds and a teaching as it were in words.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1391
verses.text: "Thou that preachest men should not steal, dost thou steal?" Therefore he that steals breaks or undoes the commandment in his deed, and as it were teaches so: "he shall be called least in the kingdom of heaven," i-e: in the Church of this present  time.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1392
verses.text: Of him it is said, "What they say do ye; but what they do, that do not ye.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1393
verses.text: But he that shall do, and shall teach so, shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1394
verses.text: From this, that He has here said, fecerit, "shall do," while in opposition to this He has there said solverit, meaning non fecerit, "shall not do, and shall teach so"â€”to break, then, is, not to doâ€”what doth He teach us, but that we should interrogate men's deeds, not take their words upon trust? The obscurity of the things compels us to speak much at length, chiefly that that which the Lord deigns to reveal may be brought within reach even of the brethren of slower understanding, because all were bought by the blood of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1395
verses.text: And I am afraid the epistle itself will not be finished during these days as I promised: but as the Lord will, it is better to reserve the remainder, than to overload your hearts with too much food.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1396
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1397
verses.text: 1 John IV.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1398
verses.text: 4â€“12  "Now are ye of God, little children, and have overcome him: because greater is He that is in you, than he that is in this world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1399
verses.text: They are of the world: therefore speak they of the world, and the world heareth them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1400
verses.text: We are of God: he that knoweth God heareth us; he that is not of God heareth not us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1401
verses.text: From this know we the spirit of truth, and [the spirit] of error.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1402
verses.text: Dearly, beloved, let us love one another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of God, and knoweth God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1403
verses.text: He that loveth not knoweth not God; for God is love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1404
verses.text: In this was manifested the love of God in us, that God sent His only-begotten Son into this world, that we may live through Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1405
verses.text: Herein is love, not that we loved, but that He loved us, and sent His Son to be the Atoner for our sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1406
verses.text: Dearly beloved, if God so loved us, we ought also to love one another.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1407
verses.text: No man hath seen God at any time".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1409
verses.text: So is this world to all the faithful seeking their own country, as was the desert to the people Israel.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1410
verses.text: They wandered indeed as yet, and were seeking their own country: but with God for their guide they could not wander astray.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1411
verses.text: Their way was God's bidding.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1412
verses.text: For where they went about during forty years, the journey itself is made up of a very few stations, and is known to all.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1413
verses.text: They were retarded because they were in training, not because they were forsaken.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1414
verses.text: That therefore which God promiseth us is ineffable sweetness and a good, as the Scripture saith, and as ye have often heard by us rehearsed, which "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither hath entered into the heart of man".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1415
verses.text: But by temporal labors we are exercised, and by temptations of this present life are trained.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1416
verses.text: Howbeit, if ye would not die of thirst in this wilderness, drink charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1417
verses.text: It is the fountain which God has been pleased to place here that we faint not in the way: and we shall more abundantly drink thereof, when we are come to our own land.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1418
verses.text: The Gospel has just been read; now to speak of the very words with which the lesson ended, what other thing heard ye but concerning charity? For we have made an agreement with our God in prayer, that if we would that He should forgive us our sins, we also should forgive the sins which may have been committed against us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1419
verses.text: Now that which forgiveth is none other than charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1420
verses.text: Take away charity from the heart; hatred possesseth it, it knows not how to forgive.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1421
verses.text: Let charity be there, and she fearlessly forgiveth, not being straitened.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1422
verses.text: And this whole epistle which we have undertaken to expound to you, see whether it commendeth aught else than this one thing, charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1423
verses.text: Nor need we fear lest by much speaking thereof it come to be hateful.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1424
verses.text: For what is there to love, if charity come to be hateful? It is by charity that other things come to be rightly loved; then how must  itself be loved! Let not that then which ought never to depart from the heart, depart from the tongue.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1426
verses.text: "Now," saith he, "are ye of God little children, and have overcome him:" whom but Antichrist? For above he had said, "Whosoever unmaketh Jesus Christ and denieth that He is come in the flesh is not of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1427
verses.text: Now we expounded, if ye remember, that all those who violate charity deny Jesus Christ to have come in the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1428
verses.text: For Jesus had no need to come but because of charity: as indeed the charity we are commending is that which the Lord Himself commendeth in the Gospel, "Greater love than this can no man have, that a man lay down his life for his friends".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1429
verses.text: How was it possible for the Son of God to lay down His life for us without putting on flesh in which He might die? Whosoever therefore violates charity, let him say what he will with his tongue, his life denies that Christ is come in the flesh; and this is an antichrist, wherever he may be, whithersoever he have come in.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1430
verses.text: But what saith the apostle to them who are citizens of that country for which we sigh? "Ye have overcome him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1431
verses.text: And whereby have they overcome? "Because greater is He that is in you, than he that is in this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1432
verses.text: Lest they should attribute the victory to their own strength, and by arrogance of pride should be overcome, (for whomsoever the devil makes proud, he overcomes,) wishing them to keep humility, what saith he? "Ye have overcome him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1433
verses.text: Every man now, at hearing this saying, "Ye have overcome," lifts up the head, lifts up the neck, wishes himself to be praised.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1434
verses.text: Do not extol thyself; see who it is that in thee hath overcome.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1435
verses.text: Why hast thou overcome? "Because greater is He that is in you, than he that is in the world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1436
verses.text: Be humble, bear thy Lord; be thou the beast for Him to sit on.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1437
verses.text: Good is it for thee that He should rule, and He guide.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1438
verses.text: For if thou have not Him to sit on thee, thou mayest lift up the neck, mayest strike out the heels: but woe to thee without a ruler, for this liberty sendeth thee among the wild beasts to be devoured!  3.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1439
verses.text: "These are of the world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1440
verses.text: Who? The antichrists.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1441
verses.text: Ye have already heard who they be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1442
verses.text: And if ye be not such, ye know them, but whosoever is such, knows not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1443
verses.text: "These are of the world: therefore speak they of the world, and the world heareth them".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1444
verses.text: Who are they that "speak of the world"? Mark who are against charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1445
verses.text: Behold, ye have heard the Lord saying, "If ye forgive men their trespasses, your heavenly Father will forgive you also your trespasses.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1446
verses.text: But if ye forgive not men their trespasses, neither will your Father forgive your trespasses".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1447
verses.text: It is the sentence of Truth: or if it be not Truth that speaks, gainsay it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1448
verses.text: If thou art a Christian and believest Christ, He hath said, "I am the truth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1449
verses.text: This sentence is true, is firm.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1450
verses.text: Now hear men that "speak of the world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1451
verses.text: "And wilt thou not avenge thyself? And wilt thou let him say that he has done this to thee? Nay: let him feel that he has to do with a man".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1452
verses.text: Every day are such things said, They that say such things, "of the world speak they, and the world heareth them".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1453
verses.text: None say such things but those that love the world, and by none are such things heard but by those who love the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1454
verses.text: And ye have heard that to love the world and neglect charity is to deny that Jesus came in the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1455
verses.text: Or say if the Lord Himself in the flesh did that? if, being buffeted, He willed to be avenged? if, hanging on the cross, He did not say, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do"? But if He threatened not, who had power; why dost thou threaten, why art thou inflated with anger, who art under power of another? He died because it was His will to die, yet He threatened not; thou knowest not when thou shalt die, and dost thou threaten?  4.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1456
verses.text: "We are of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1457
verses.text: Let us see why; see whether it be for any other thing than charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1458
verses.text: "We are of God: he that knoweth God heareth us; he that is not of God heareth not us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1459
verses.text: Hereby know we the spirit of truth, and of error:" namely by this, that he that heareth us hath the spirit of truth; he that heareth not us, hath the spirit of error.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1460
verses.text: Let us see what he adviseth, and let us choose rather to hear him advising in the spirit of truth, and not antichrists, not lovers of the world, not the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1461
verses.text: If we are born of God, "beloved," he goes onâ€”see above from what: "We are of God: he that knoweth God heareth us; he that is not of God heareth not us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1462
verses.text: Hereby know we the spirit of truth, and of error:" aye, now, he makes us eagerly attentive: to be told that he who knows God, hears; but he who knows not, hears not; and that this is the discerning between the spirit of truth and the spirit of error: well then, let us see what he is about to advise; in what we must hear himâ€”"Beloved, let us love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1463
verses.text: Why? because a man adviseth? "Because love is of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1464
verses.text: Much hath he commended love, in that he hath said, "Is of  God:" but he is going to say more; let us eagerly hear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1465
verses.text: At present he hath said, "Love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of God, and knoweth God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1466
verses.text: He that loveth not knoweth not God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1467
verses.text: Why? "For God is love" [Love is God].

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1468
verses.text: What more could be said, brethren? If nothing were said in praise of love throughout the pages of this epistle, if nothing whatever throughout the other pages of the Scriptures, and this one only thing were all we were told by the voice of the Spirit of God, "For Love is God;" nothing more ought we to require.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1470
verses.text: Now see that to act against love is to act against God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1471
verses.text: Let no man say, "I sin against man when I do not love my brother, (mark it!) and sin against man is a thing to be taken easily; only let me not sin against God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1472
verses.text: How sinnest thou not against God, when thou sinnest against love? "Love is God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1473
verses.text: Do "we" say this? If we said, "Love is God," haply some one of you might be offended and say, What hath he said? What meant he to say, that "Love is God"? God "gave" love, as a gift God bestowed love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1474
verses.text: "Love is of God: Love IS God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1475
verses.text: Look, here have ye, brethren, the Scriptures of God: this epistle is canonical; throughout all nations it is recited, it is held by the authority of the whole earth, it hath edified the whole earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1476
verses.text: Thou art here told by the Spirit of God, "Love is God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1477
verses.text: Now if thou dare, go against God, and refuse to love thy brother!  6.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1478
verses.text: In what sense then was it said a while ago, "Love is of God;" and now, "Love IS God?" For God is Father and Son and Holy Ghost: the Son, God of God, the Holy Ghost, God of God; and these three, one God, not three Gods.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1479
verses.text: If the Son be God, and the Holy Ghost God, and that person loveth in whom dwelleth the Holy Ghost: therefore "Love is God;" but "IS God," because "Of God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1480
verses.text: For thou hast both in the epistle; both, "Love is of God," and, "Love is God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1481
verses.text: Of the Father alone the Scripture hath it not to say, that He is "of God:" but when thou hearest that expression, "Of God," either the Son is meant, or the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1482
verses.text: Because while the apostle saith, "The love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given unto us:" let us understand that He who subsisteth in love is the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1483
verses.text: For it is even this Holy Spirit, whom the bad cannot receive, even He is that Fountain of which the Scripture saith, "Let the fountain of thy water be thine own, and let no stranger partake with thee".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1484
verses.text: For all who love not God, are strangers, are antichrists.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1485
verses.text: And though they come to the churches, they cannot be numbered among the children of God; not to them belongeth that Fountain of life.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1486
verses.text: To have baptism is possible even for a bad man; to have prophecy is possible even for a bad man.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1487
verses.text: We find that king Saul had prophecy: he was persecuting holy David, yet was he filled with the spirit of prophecy, and began to prophesy.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1488
verses.text: To receive the sacrament of the body and blood of the Lord is possible even for a bad man: for of such it is said, "He that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh judgment to himself".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1489
verses.text: To have the name of Christ is possible even for a bad man; i-e: even a bad man can be called a Christian: as they of whom it is said, "They polluted the name of their God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1490
verses.text: I say, to have all these sacraments is possible even for a bad man; but to have charity, and to be a bad man, is not possible.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1491
verses.text: This then is the peculiar gift, this the "Fountain" that is singly one's "own".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1492
verses.text: To drink of this the Spirit of God exhorteth you, to drink of Himself the Spirit of God exhorteth you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1494
verses.text: "In this was manifested the love of God in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1495
verses.text: Behold, in order that we may love God, we have exhortation.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1496
verses.text: Could we love Him, unless He first loved us? If we were slow to love, let us not be slow to love in return.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1497
verses.text: He first loved us; not even so do we love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1498
verses.text: He loved the unrighteous, but He did away the unrighteousness: He loved the unrighteous, but not unto unrighteousness did He gather them together: He loved the sick, but He visited them to make them whole.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1499
verses.text: "Love," then, "is God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1500
verses.text: "In this was manifested the love of God in us, because that God sent His only-begotten Son into the world, that we may live through Him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1501
verses.text: As the Lord Himself saith: "Greater love than this can no man have, that a man lay down his life for his friends:" and there was proved the love of Christ towards us, in that He died for us: how is the love of the Father towards us proved? In that He "sent His only Son" to die for us: so also the apostle Paul saith: "He that spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how hath He not with Him also freely given us all  things?" Behold the Father delivered up Christ; Judas delivered Him up; does it not seem as if the thing done were of the same sort? Judas is "traditor," one that delivered up, [or, a traitor]: is God the Father that? God forbid! sayest thou.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1502
verses.text: I do not say it, but the apostle saith, "He that spared not His own Son, but "tradidit Eum" delivered Him up for us all".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1503
verses.text: Both the Father delivered Him up, and He delivered up Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1504
verses.text: The same apostle saith: "Who loved me, and delivered Himself up for me".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1505
verses.text: If the Father delivered up the Son; and the Son delivered up Himself, what has Judas done? There was a "traditio" (delivering up) by the Father; there was a "traditio" by the Son; there was a "traditio" by Judas: the thing done is the same, but what is it that distinguishes the Father delivering up the Son, the Son delivering up Himself, and Judas the disciple delivering up his Master? This: that the Father and the Son did it in love, but Judas did this in treacherous betrayal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1506
verses.text: Ye see that not what the man does is the thing to be considered; but with what mind and will he does it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1507
verses.text: We find God the Father in the same deed in which we find Judas; the Father we bless, Judas we detest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1508
verses.text: Why do we bless the Father, and detest Judas? We bless charity, detest iniquity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1509
verses.text: How great a good was conferred upon mankind by the delivering up of Christ! Had Judas this in his thoughts, that therefore he delivered Him up? God had in His thoughts our salvation by which we were redeemed; Judas had in his thoughts the price for which he sold the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1510
verses.text: The Son Himself had in His thoughts the price He gave for us, Judas in his the price he received to sell Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1511
verses.text: The diverse intention therefore makes the things done diverse.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1512
verses.text: Though the thing be one, yet if we measure it by the diverse intentions, we find the one a thing to be loved, the other to be condemned; the one we find a thing to be glorified, the other to be detested.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1513
verses.text: Such is the force of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1514
verses.text: See that it alone discriminates, it alone distinguishes the doings of men.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1516
verses.text: This we have said in the case where the things done are similar.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1517
verses.text: In the case where they are diverse, we find a man by charity made fierce; and by iniquity made winningly gentle.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1518
verses.text: A father beats a boy, and a boy-stealer caresses.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1519
verses.text: If thou name the two things, blows and caresses, who would not choose the caresses, and decline the blows? If thou mark the persons, it is charity that beats, iniquity that caresses.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1520
verses.text: See what we are insisting upon; that the deeds of men are only discerned by the root of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1521
verses.text: For many things may be done that have a good appearance, and yet proceed not from the root of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1522
verses.text: For thorns also have flowers: some actions truly seem rough, seem savage; howbeit they are done for discipline at the bidding of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1523
verses.text: Once for all, then, a short precept is given thee: Love, and do what thou wilt: whether thou hold thy peace, through love hold thy peace; whether thou cry out, through love cry out; whether thou correct, through love correct; whether thou spare, through love do thou spare: let the root of love be within, of this root can nothing spring but what is good.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1525
verses.text: "In this is loveâ€”in this was manifested the love of God toward us, because that God sent his only-begotten Son into this world, that we may live through Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1526
verses.text: â€”In this is love, not that we loved God, but that He loved us:" we did not love Him first: for to this end loved He us, that we may love Him: "And sent His Son to be the Atoner for our sins: "litatorem," i-e: one that sacrifices.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1527
verses.text: He sacrificed for our sins.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1528
verses.text: Where did He find the sacrifice? Where did He find the victim which he would offer pure? Other He found none; His own self He offered.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1529
verses.text: "Beloved, if God so loved us we ought also to love one another.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1530
verses.text: Peter," saith He, "lovest thou me?" And he said, "I love".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1531
verses.text: "Feed my sheep".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1533
verses.text: "No man hath seen God at any time:" He is a thing invisible; not with the eye but with the heart must He be sought.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1534
verses.text: But just as if we wished to see the sun, we should purge the eye of the body; wishing to see God, let us purge the eye by which God can be seen.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1535
verses.text: Where is this eye? Hear the Gospel: "Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1536
verses.text: But let no man imagine God to himself according to the lust of his eyes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1537
verses.text: For so he makes unto himself either a huge form, or a certain incalculable magnitude which, like the light which he sees with the bodily eyes, he makes extend through all directions; field after field of space he gives it all the bigness he can; or, he represents to himself like as it were an old man of venerable form.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1538
verses.text: None of these things do thou imagine.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1539
verses.text: There is something thou mayest imagine, if thou wouldest see God; "God is love".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1540
verses.text: What sort of face hath love? what form hath it? what stature? what feet? what hands hath it? no man can say.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1541
verses.text: And yet it hath feet, for these carry men to church: it hath hands; for these reach forth to the poor: it hath eyes; for thereby we consider the  needy: "Blessed is the man," it is said, "who considereth the needy and the poor".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1542
verses.text: It hath ears, of which the Lord saith, "He that hath ears to hear let him hear".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1543
verses.text: These are not members distinct by place, but with the understanding he that hath charity sees the whole at once.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1544
verses.text: Inhabit, and thou shalt be inhabited; dwell, and thou shalt be dwelt in.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1545
verses.text: For how say you, my brethren? who loves what he does not see? Now why, when charity is praised, do ye lift up your hands, make acclaim, praise? What have I shown you? What I produced, was it a gleam of colors? What I propounded, was it gold and silver? Have I dug out jewels from hid treasures? What of this sort have I shown to your eyes? Is my face changed while I speak? I am in the flesh; I am in the same form in which I came forth to you; ye are in the same form in which ye came hither: charity is praised, and ye shout applause.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1546
verses.text: Certainly ye see nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1547
verses.text: But as it pleases you when ye praise, so let it please you that ye may keep it in your heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1548
verses.text: For mark well what I say brethren; I exhort you all, as God enables me, unto a great treasure.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1549
verses.text: If there were shown you a beautiful little vase, embossed, inlaid with gold, curiously wrought, and it charmed your eyes, and drew towards it the eager desire of your heart, and you were pleased with the hand of the artificer, and the weight of the silver, and the splendor of the metal; would not each one of you say, "O, if I had that vase!" And to no purpose ye would say it, for it would not rest with you to have it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1550
verses.text: Or if one should wish to have it, he might think of stealing it from another's house.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1551
verses.text: Charity is praised to you; if it please you, have it, possess it: no need that ye should rob any man, no need that ye should think of buying it; it is to be had freely, without cost.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1552
verses.text: Take it, clasp it; there is nothing sweeter.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1553
verses.text: If such it be when it is but spoken of, what must it be when one has it?  11.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1554
verses.text: If any of you perchance wish to keep charity, brethren, above all things do not imagine it to be an abject and sluggish thing; nor that charity is to be preserved by a sort of gentleness, nay not gentleness, but tameness and listlessness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1555
verses.text: Not so is it preserved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1556
verses.text: Do not imagine that thou then lovest thy servant when thou dost not beat him, or that thou then lovest thy son when thou givest him not discipline, or that thou then lovest thy neighbor when thou dost not rebuke him: this is not charity, but mere feebleness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1557
verses.text: Let charity be fervent to correct, to amend: but if there be good manners, let them delight thee; if bad, let them be amended, let them be corrected.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1558
verses.text: Love not in the man his error, but the man: for the man God made, the error the man himself made.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1559
verses.text: Love that which God made, love not that which the man himself made.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1560
verses.text: When thou lovest that, thou takest away this: when thou esteemest that, thou amendest this.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1561
verses.text: But even if thou be severe at any time, let it be because of love, for correction.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1562
verses.text: For this cause was charity betokened by the Dove which descended upon the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1563
verses.text: That likeness of a dove, the likeness in which came the Holy Ghost, by whom charity should be shed forth into us: wherefore was this? The dove hath no gall: yet with beak and wings she fights for her young; hers is a fierceness without bitterness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1564
verses.text: And so does also a father; when he chastises his son, for discipline he chastises him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1565
verses.text: As I said, the kidnapper, in order that he may sell, inveigles the child with bitter endearments; a father, that he may correct, does without gall chastise.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1566
verses.text: Such be ye to all men.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1567
verses.text: See here, brethren, a great lesson, a great rule: each one of you has children, or wishes to have; or if he has altogether determined to have no children after the flesh, at least spiritually he desires to have children:â€”what father does not correct his son? what son does not his father discipline? And yet he seems to be fierce with him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1568
verses.text: It is the fierceness of love, the fierceness of charity: a sort of fierceness without gall after the manner of the dove, not of the raven.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1569
verses.text: Whence it came into my mind, my brethren, to tell you, that those violaters of charity are they that have made the schism: as they hate charity itself, so they hate also the dove.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1570
verses.text: But the dove convicts them: it comes forth from heaven, the heavens open, and it abideth on the head of the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1571
verses.text: Wherefore this? That John may hear, "This is He that baptizeth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1572
verses.text: Away, ye robbers; away, ye invaders of the possession of Christ! On your own possessions, where ye will needs be lords, ye have dared to fix the titles of the great Owner.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1573
verses.text: He recognizes His own titles; He vindicates to Himself His own possession.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1574
verses.text: He does not cancel the titles, but enters in and takes possession.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1575
verses.text: So in one that comes to the Catholic Church, his baptism is not cancelled, that the title of the commander be not cancelled: but what is done in the Catholic Church? The title is acknowledged; the Owner enters in under His own titles, where the robber was entering in under titles not his own.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1576
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1577
verses.text: 1 John IV.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1578
verses.text: 12â€“16  "If we love one another, God abideth in us, and His love will be perfected in us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1579
verses.text: In this know we that we abide in Him, and He in us, because He hath given us of His Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1580
verses.text: And we have seen and are witnesses that the Father sent the Son to be the Saviour of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1581
verses.text: Whosoever shall confess that Jesus is the Son of God, God abideth in him, and he in God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1582
verses.text: And we have known and believed the love that God hath to us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1583
verses.text: God is love; and he that abideth in love abideth in God, and God abideth in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1585
verses.text: Love is a sweet word, but sweeter the deed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1586
verses.text: To be always speaking of it, is not in our power: for we have many things to do, and divers businesses draw us different ways, so that our tongue has not leisure to be always speaking of love: as indeed our tongue could have nothing better to do.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1587
verses.text: But though we may not always be speaking of it, we may always keep it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1588
verses.text: Just as it is with the Alleluia which we sing at this present time, are we always doing this? Not one hour, I do not say for the whole space of it, do we sing Alleluia, but barely during a few moments of one hour, and then give ourselves to something else.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1589
verses.text: Now Alleluia, as ye already know, means, Praise ye the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1590
verses.text: He that praises God with his tongue, cannot be always doing this: he that by his life and conduct praises God, can be doing it always.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1591
verses.text: Works of mercy, affections of charity, sanctity of piety, incorruptness of chastity, modesty of sobriety, these things are always to be practiced: whether we are in public, or at home; whether before men, or in our chamber; whether speaking, or holding our peace; whether occupied upon something, or free from occupation: these are always to be kept, because all these virtues which I have named are within.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1592
verses.text: But who is sufficient to name them all? There is as it were the army of an emperor seated within in thy mind.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1593
verses.text: For as an emperor by his army does what he will, so the Lord Jesus Christ, once beginning to dwell in our inner man, (i-e: in the mind through faith), uses these virtues as His ministers.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1594
verses.text: And by these virtues which cannot be seen with eyes, and yet when they are named are praisedâ€”and they would not be praised except they were loved, not loved except they were seen; and if not loved except seen, they are seen with another eye, that is, with the inward beholding of the heartâ€”by these invisible virtues, the members are visibly put in motion: the feet to walk, but whither? whither they are moved by the good will which as a soldier serves the good emperor: the hands to work; but what? that which is bidden by charity which is inspired within by the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1595
verses.text: The members then are seen when they are put in motion; He that orders them within is not seen: and who He is that orders them within is known almost alone to Him that orders, and to him who within is ordered.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1597
verses.text: For, brethren, ye heard just now when the Gospel was read, at least if ye had for it the ear not only of the body but also of the heart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1598
verses.text: What said it? "Take heed that ye do not your righteousness before men, to be seen of them".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1599
verses.text: Did He mean to say this, that whatever good things we do, we should hide them from the eyes of men, and fear to be seen? If thou fearest spectators thou wilt not have imitators: thou oughtest therefore to be seen.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1600
verses.text: But thou must not do it to the end thou mayest be seen.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1601
verses.text: Not there should be the end of thy joy, not there the goal of thy rejoicing, that thou shouldest account thyself to have gotten the whole fruit of thy good work, when thou art seen and praised.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1602
verses.text: This is nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1603
verses.text: Despise thyself when thou art praised, let Him be praised in thee who worketh by thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1604
verses.text: Therefore do not for thine own praise work the good thou doest: but to the praise of Him from whom thou hast the power to do good.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1605
verses.text: From thy  self thou hast the ill doing, from God thou hast the well doing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1606
verses.text: On the other hand, see perverse men, how preposterous they are.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1607
verses.text: What they do well, they will needs ascribe to themselves; if they do ill, they will needs accuse God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1608
verses.text: Reverse this distorted and preposterous proceeding, which puts the thing, as one may say, head downwards, which makes that undermost which is uppermost, and that upwards which is downwards.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1609
verses.text: Dost thou want to make God undermost and thyself uppermost? Thou goest headlong, not elevatest thyself; for He is always above.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1610
verses.text: What then? thou well, and God ill? nay rather, say this, if thou wouldest speak more truly, I ill, He well; and what I do well from Him is the well-doing: for from myself whatever I do is ill.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1611
verses.text: This confession strengthens the heart, and makes a firm foundation of love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1612
verses.text: For if we ought to hide our good works lest they be seen of men, what becomes of that sentence of the Lord in the sermon which He delivered on the mount? Where He said this, there He also said a little before, "Let your good works shine before men".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1613
verses.text: And He did not stop there, did not there make an end, but added, "And glorify your Father which is in Heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1614
verses.text: And what saith the apostle? "And I was unknown by face unto the Churches of Judea which were in Christ: but they heard only, That he which persecuted us in times past, now preacheth the faith which once he destroyed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1615
verses.text: And in me they glorified God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1616
verses.text: See how he also, in regard that he became so widely known did not set the good in his own praise, but in the praise of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1617
verses.text: And as for him, in his own person, that he was one who laid waste the Church, a persecutor, envious, malignant, it is himself that confesses this, not we that reproach him therewith.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1618
verses.text: Paul loves to have his sins spoken of by us, that He may be glorified who healed such a disease.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1619
verses.text: For it was the hand of the Physician that cut and healed the greatness of the sore.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1620
verses.text: That voice from heaven prostrated the persecutor, and raised up the preacher; killed Saul, and quickened Paul.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1621
verses.text: For Saul was the persecutor of a holy man; thence had this man his name, when he persecuted the Christians: afterward of Saul he became Paul.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1622
verses.text: What does the name Paulus mean? Little.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1623
verses.text: Therefore when he was Saul, he was proud, lifted up; when he was Paul, he was lowly, little.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1624
verses.text: Thus we say, I will see thee "paulo post," i-e: after a little while.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1625
verses.text: Hear that he was made little: "For I am the least of the apostles; and, To me the least of all saints," he saith in another place.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1626
verses.text: So was he among the apostles as the hem of the garment: but the Church of the Gentiles touched it, as did the woman which had the flux, and was made whole.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1628
verses.text: Then, brethren, this I would say, this I do say, this if I might I would not leave unsaid: Let there be in you now these works, now those, according to the time, according to the hours, according to the days.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1629
verses.text: Are you always to be speaking? always to keep silence? always to be refreshing the body? always to be fasting? always to be giving bread to the needy? always to be clothing the naked? always to be visiting the sick? always to be bringing into agreement them that disagree? always to be burying the dead? No: but now this, now that.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1630
verses.text: These things are taken in hand, and they stop: but that which as emperor commands all the forces within neither hath beginning nor ought to stop.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1631
verses.text: Let charity within have no intermission: let the offices of charity be exhibited according to the time.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1632
verses.text: Let "brotherly love" then, as it is written, let "brotherly love continue".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1634
verses.text: But perchance it will have struck some of you all along, while we have been expounding to you this epistle of blessed John, why it is only "brotherly" love that he so emphatically commends.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1635
verses.text: "He that loveth his brother," saith he: and, "a commandment is given us that we love one another".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1636
verses.text: Again and again it is of brotherly love that he speaks: but the love of God, i-e: the love with which we ought to love God, he has not so constantly named; howbeit, he has not altogether left it unspoken.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1637
verses.text: But concerning love of an enemy, almost throughout the epistle, he has said nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1638
verses.text: Although he vehemently preaches up and commends charity to us, he does not tell us to love our enemies, but tells us to love our brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1639
verses.text: But just now, when the Gospel was read, we heard, "For if ye love them that love you, what reward shall ye have? Do not even the publicans this?"
