How is it then that John  the apostle, as the thing of great concern to us in order to a certain perfection, commends brotherly love; whereas the Lord saith it is not enough that we love our brethren, but that we ought to extend that love so that we may reach even to enemies? He that reaches even unto enemies does not overleap the brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1640
verses.text: It must needs, like fire, first seize upon what is nearest, and so extend to what is further off.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1641
verses.text: A brother is nearer to thee than any chance person.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1642
verses.text: Again, that person has more hold upon thee whom thou knowest not, who yet is not against thee, than an enemy who is also against thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1643
verses.text: Extend thy love to them that are nearest, yet do not call this an extending: for it is almost loving thyself, to love them that are close to thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1644
verses.text: Extend it to the unknown, who have done thee no ill.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1645
verses.text: Pass even them: reach on to love thine enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1646
verses.text: This at least the Lord commands.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1647
verses.text: Why has the apostle here said nothing about loving an enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1649
verses.text: All love, whether that which is called carnal, which is wont to be called not "dilectio" but "amor:" (for the word "dilectio" is wont to be used of better objects, and to be understood of better objects:) yet all love, dear brethren, hath in it a wishing well to those who are loved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1650
verses.text: For we ought not so to love, nor are we able so to love, (whether "diligere" or "amare:" for this latter word the Lord used when He said, "Petra, amas me?" "Peter, lovest thou me?") we ought not so to love men, as we hear gluttons say, I love thrushes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1651
verses.text: Thou askest why he loves them? That he may kill, that he may consume.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1652
verses.text: He says he loves, and to this end loves he them, that they may cease to be; to this end loves he them, that he may make away with them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1653
verses.text: And whatever we love in the way of food, to this end love we it, that it may be consumed and we recruited.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1654
verses.text: Are men to be so loved as to be consumed? But there is a certain friendliness of well wishing, by which we desire at some time or other to do good to those whom we love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1655
verses.text: How if there be no good that we can do? The benevolence, the wishing well, of itself sufficeth him that loves.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1656
verses.text: For we ought not to wish men to be wretched, that we may be enabled to practise works of mercy.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1657
verses.text: Thou givest bread to the hungry: but better it were that none hungered, and thou hadst none to give to.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1658
verses.text: Thou clothest the naked: oh that all were clothed, and this need existed not! Thou buriest the dead: oh that it were come at last, that life where none shall die! Thou reconcilest the quarrelling: oh that it were here at last, that eternal peace of Jerusalem, where none shall disagree! For all these are offices done to necessities.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1659
verses.text: Take away the wretched; there will be an end to works of mercy.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1660
verses.text: The works of mercy will be at an end: shall the ardor of charity be quenched? With a truer touch of love thou lovest the happy man, to whom there is no good office thou canst do; purer will that love be, and far more unalloyed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1661
verses.text: For if thou have done a kindness to the wretched, perchance thou desirest to lift up thyself over against him, and wishest him to be subject to thee, who hast done the kindness to him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1662
verses.text: He was in need, thou didst bestow; thou seemest to thyself greater because thou didst bestow, than he upon whom it was bestowed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1663
verses.text: Wish him thine equal, that ye both may be under the One Lord, on whom nothing can be bestowed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1665
verses.text: For in this the proud soul has passed bounds, and, in a manner, become avaricious.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1666
verses.text: For, "The root of all evils is avarice;" and again it is said, "The beginning of all sin is pride".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1667
verses.text: And we ask, it may be, how these two sentences agree: "The root of all evils is avarice;" and, "The beginning of all sin is pride".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1668
verses.text: If pride is the beginning of all sin, then is pride the root of all evils.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1669
verses.text: Now certainly, "the root of all evils is avarice".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1670
verses.text: We find that in pride there is also avarice, (or grasping;) for man has passed bounds: and what is it to be avaricious to go beyond that which sufficeth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1671
verses.text: Adam fell by pride: "the beginning of all sin is pride," saith it: did he fall by grasping? What more grasping, than he whom God could not suffice? In fact, my brethren, we read how man was made after the image and likeness of God: and what said God of him? "And let him have power over the fishes of the sea, and over the fowl of the heaven, and over all cattle which move upon the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1672
verses.text: Said He, Have power over men? "Have power," saith He: He hath given him natural power: "have power" over what? "over the fishes of the sea, the fowl of the heaven, and all moving things which move upon the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1673
verses.text: Why is this power over these things a natural power? Because man hath the power from this; that he was made after the image of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1674
verses.text: And in what was he made after God's image? In the intellect, in the mind, in the inner man; in that he understands truth, distinguishes between right and wrong, knows by whom he was made, is able to understand his Creator, to praise his Creator: he hath this intelligence, who hath prudence.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1675
verses.text: Therefore  when many by evil lusts wore out in themselves the image of God, and by perversity of their manners extinguished the very flame, so to say, of intelligence, the Scripture cried aloud to them, "Become not ye as the horse and mule which have no understanding".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1676
verses.text: That is to say, I have set thee above the horse and mule; thee, I made after mine image, I have given thee power over these.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1677
verses.text: Why? Because they have not the rational mind: but thou by the rational mind art capable of truth, understandest what is above thee: be subject to Him that is above thee, and beneath thee shall those things be over which thou was set.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1678
verses.text: But because by sin man deserted Him whom he ought to be under, he is made subject to the things which he ought to be above.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1680
verses.text: Mark what I say: God, man, beasts: to wit, above thee, God; beneath thee, the beasts.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1681
verses.text: Acknowledge Him that is above thee, that those that are beneath thee may acknowledge thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1682
verses.text: Thus, because Daniel acknowledged God above him, the lions acknowledged him above them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1683
verses.text: But if thou acknowledge not Him that is above thee, thou despisest thy superior, thou becomest subject to thine inferior.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1684
verses.text: Accordingly, how was the pride of the Egyptians quelled? By the means of frogs and flies.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1685
verses.text: God might have sent lions: but a great man may be scared by a lion.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1686
verses.text: The prouder they were, the more by the means of things contemptible and feeble was their wicked neck broken.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1687
verses.text: But Daniel, lions acknowledge, because he was subject to God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1688
verses.text: What the martyrs who were cast to the wild beasts to fight with them, and were torn by the teeth of savage creatures, were they not under God? or were those three men servants of God, and the Maccabees not servants of God? The fire acknowledged as God's servants the three men, whom it burned not, neither hurt their garments; and did it not acknowledge the Maccabees? It acknowledged the Maccabees; it did, my brethren, acknowledge them also.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1689
verses.text: But there was need of a scourge, by the Lord's permission: He hath said in Scripture, "He scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1690
verses.text: For think ye, my brethren, the iron would have pierced into the vitals of the Lord unless He had permitted it, or that He would have hung fastened to the tree, unless it had been His will? Did not His own creature acknowledge Him? Or did He set an ensample of patience to His faithful ones? Ye see then, God delivered some visibly, some He delivered not visibly: yet all He spiritually delivered, spiritually deserted none.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1691
verses.text: Visibly He seemed to have deserted some, some He seemed to have rescued.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1692
verses.text: Therefore rescued He some, that thou mayest not think that He had not power to rescue.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1693
verses.text: He has given proof that He has the power, to the end that where he doth it not, thou mayest understand a more secret will, not surmise difficulty of doing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1694
verses.text: But what, brethren? When we shall have come out of all these snares of mortality, when the times of temptation shall have passed away, when the river of this world shall have fleeted by, and we shall have received again that "first robe," that immortality which by sinning we have lost, "when this corruptible shall have put on incorruption," that is, this flesh shall have put on incorruption, "and this mortal shall have put on immortality;" the now perfected sons of God, in whom is no more need to be tempted, neither to be scourged, shall all creatures acknowledge: subjected to us shall all things be, if we here be subjected to God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1696
verses.text: So then ought the Christian to be, that he glory not over other "men".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1697
verses.text: For God hath given it thee to be over the beasts, i-e: to be better than the beasts.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1698
verses.text: This hast thou by nature; thou shalt always be better than a beast.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1699
verses.text: If thou wish to be better than another man, thou wilt begrudge him when thou shalt see him to be thine equal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1700
verses.text: Thou oughtest to wish all men to be thine equals; and if by wisdom thou surpass any, thou oughtest to wish that he also may be wise.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1701
verses.text: As long as he is slow, he learns from thee; as long as he is untaught, he hath need of thee; and thou art seen to be the teacher, he the learner; therefore thou seemest to be the superior, because thou art the teacher; he the inferior, because the learner.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1702
verses.text: Except thou wish him thine equal, thou wishest to have him always a learner.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1703
verses.text: But if thou wish to have him always a learner, thou wilt be an envious teacher.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1704
verses.text: If an envious teacher, how wilt thou be a teacher? I pray thee, do not teach him thine enviousness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1705
verses.text: Hear the apostle speaking of the bowels of charity: "I would that all were even as I".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1706
verses.text: In what sense did he wish all to be his equals? In this was he superior to all, that by charity he wished all to be his equals.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1707
verses.text: I say then, man  has past bounds; he would needs be greedy of more than his due, would be above men, he that was made above the beasts: and this is pride.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1709
verses.text: And see what great works pride does.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1710
verses.text: Lay it up in your hearts, how much alike, how much as it were upon a par, are the works it doeth, and the works of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1711
verses.text: Charity feeds the hungry, and so does pride: charity, that God may be praised; pride, that itself may be praised.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1712
verses.text: Charity clothes the naked, so does pride: charity fasts, so does pride: charity buries the dead, so does pride.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1713
verses.text: All good works which charity wishes to do, and does; pride, on the other hand, drives at the same, and, so to say, keeps her horses up to the mark.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1714
verses.text: But charity is between her and it, and leaves not place for ill-driven pride; not ill-driving, but ill-driven.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1715
verses.text: Woe to the man whose charioteer is pride, for he must needs go headlong! But that, in the good that is done, it may not be pride that sets us on, who knows? who sees it? where is it? the works we see: mercy feeds, pride also feeds; mercy takes in the stranger, pride also takes in the stranger; mercy intercedes for the poor, pride also intercedes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1716
verses.text: How is this? In the works we see no difference.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1717
verses.text: I dare to say somewhat, but not I; Paul hath said it: charity dies, that is, a man having charity confesses the name of Christ, suffers martyrdom: pride also confesses, suffers also martyrdom.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1718
verses.text: The one hath charity, the other hath not charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1719
verses.text: But let him that hath not charity hear from the apostle: "If I distribute all my goods to the poor, and if I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1720
verses.text: So then the divine Scripture calls us off from the display of the face outwardly to that which is within; from this surface which is vaunted before men, it calls us off to that which is within.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1721
verses.text: Return to thy own conscience, question it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1722
verses.text: Do not consider what blossoms outwardly, but what root there is in the ground.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1723
verses.text: Is lust rooted there? A show there may be of good deeds, truly good works there cannot be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1724
verses.text: Is charity rooted there? Have no fear: nothing evil can come of that.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1725
verses.text: The proud caresses, love is severe.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1726
verses.text: The one clothes, the other smites.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1727
verses.text: For the one clothes in order to please men, the other smites in order to correct by discipline.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1728
verses.text: More accepted is the blow of charity than the alms of pride.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1729
verses.text: Come then within, brethren; and in all things, whatsoever ye do, look unto God your witness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1730
verses.text: See, if He seeth, with what mind ye do it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1731
verses.text: If your heart accuse you not that ye do it for the sake of display, it is well: fear ye not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1732
verses.text: But when ye do good, fear not lest another see you.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1733
verses.text: Fear thou lest thou do it to the end that thou mayest be praised: let the other see it, that God may be praised.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1734
verses.text: For if thou hidest it from the eyes of man, thou hidest it from the imitation of man, thou withdrawest from God His praise.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1735
verses.text: Two are there to whom thou doest the alms: two hunger; one for bread, the other for righteousness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1736
verses.text: Between these two famishing souls:â€”as it is written, "Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled:"â€”between these two famishing persons thou the doer of the good work art set; if charity does the work by occasion of the one, therein it hath pity on both, it would succor both.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1737
verses.text: For the one craves what he may eat, the other craves what he may imitate.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1738
verses.text: Thou feedest the one, give thyself as a pattern to the other; so hast thou given alms to both: the one thou hast caused to thank thee for killing his hunger, the other thou hast made to imitate thee by setting him an example.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1740
verses.text: Shew mercy then, as men of merciful hearts; because in loving enemies also, ye love brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1741
verses.text: Think not that John has given no precept concerning love of our enemy, because he has not ceased to speak of brotherly love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1742
verses.text: Ye love brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1743
verses.text: "How," sayest thou, "do we love brethren?" I ask wherefore thou lovest an enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1744
verses.text: Wherefore dost thou love him? That he may be whole in this life? what if it be not expedient for him? That he may be rich? what if by his very riches he shall be blinded? That he may marry a wife? what if he shall have a bitter life of it? That he may have children? what if they shall be bad? Uncertain therefore are these things which thou seemest to wish for thine enemy, in that thou lovest him; they are uncertain.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1745
verses.text: Wish for him that he may have with thee eternal life; wish for him that he may be thy brother: when thou lovest him, thou lovest a brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1746
verses.text: For thou lovest in him not what he is, but what thou wishest that he may be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1747
verses.text: I once said to you, my beloved, if I mistake not: There is a log of timber lying in sight; a good workman has seen the log, not yet planed, just as it was hewn from the forest, he has taken a liking to it, he would make something out of it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1748
verses.text: For indeed he did not love it to this end that it should always remain thus.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1749
verses.text: In his art he has seen what it shall be, not in his liking what it is; and his liking is for the thing he will make of it, not  for the thing it is.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1750
verses.text: So God loved us sinners.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1751
verses.text: We say that God loved sinners: for He saith, "They that are whole need not the Physician, but they that are sick".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1752
verses.text: Did He love us sinners to the end we should still remain sinners? As timber from the wood our Carpenter saw us, and had in His thoughts the building He would make thereof, not the unwrought timber that it was.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1753
verses.text: So too thou seest thine enemy striving against thee, raging, biting with words, exasperating with contumelies, harassing with hatred: thou hast regard to this in him, that he is a man.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1754
verses.text: Thou seest all these things that are against thee, that they were done by man; and thou seest in him that he was made by God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1755
verses.text: Now that he was made man, was God's doing: but that he hates thee, is his doing; that he has ill-will at thee, is his doing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1756
verses.text: And what sayest thou in thy mind? Lord, be merciful to him, forgive him his sins, strike terror into him, change him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1757
verses.text: Thou lovest not in him what he is, but what thou wishest him to be.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1758
verses.text: Consequently, when thou lovest an enemy, thou lovest a brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1759
verses.text: Wherefore, perfect love is the loving an enemy: which perfect love is in brotherly love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1760
verses.text: And let no man say that John the apostle has admonished us somewhat less, and the Lord Christ somewhat more.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1761
verses.text: John has admonished us to love the brethren; Christ has admonished us to love even enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1762
verses.text: Mark to what end Christ hath bidden thee to love thine enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1763
verses.text: That they may remain always enemies? If He bade it for this end, that they should remain enemies, thou hatest, not lovest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1764
verses.text: Mark how He Himself loved, i-e: because He would not that they should be still the persecutors they were, He said, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1765
verses.text: Whom He willed to be forgiven, them He willed to be changed: whom He willed to be changed, of enemies He deigned to make brethren, and did in truth make them so.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1766
verses.text: He was killed, was buried, rose again, ascended into heaven: sent the Holy Ghost to His disciples: they began with boldness to preach His name, they did miracles in the name of Him that was crucified and slain: those slayers of the Lord saw them; and they who in rage had shed His blood, by believing drank it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1768
verses.text: These things have I said, brethren, and somewhat at length: yet because charity was to be more earnestly commended to you, beloved, in this way was it to be commended.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1769
verses.text: For if there be no charity in you, we have said nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1770
verses.text: But if it be in you, we have as it were cast oil upon the flames.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1771
verses.text: And in whom it was not, perchance by words it hath been kindled.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1772
verses.text: In one; that which was there hath grown; in another, that hath begun to be, which was not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1773
verses.text: To this end therefore have we said these things, that ye be not slow to love your enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1774
verses.text: Does any man rage against thee? he rages, pray thou; he hates, pity thou.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1775
verses.text: It is the fever of his soul that hates thee: he will be whole, and will thank thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1776
verses.text: How do physicians love them that are sick? Is it the sick that they love? If they love them as sick, they wish them to be always sick.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1777
verses.text: To this end love they the sick; not that they should still be sick, but that from being sick they should be made whole.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1778
verses.text: And how much have they very often to suffer from the frenzied! What contumelious language! Very often they are even struck by them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1779
verses.text: He attacks the fever, forgives the man.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1780
verses.text: And what shall I say, brethren? does he love his enemy? Nay, he hates his enemy, the disease; for it is this that he hates, and loves the man by whom he is struck: he hates the fever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1781
verses.text: For by whom or by what is he struck? by the disease, by the sickness, by the fever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1782
verses.text: He takes away that which strives against him, that there may remain that from which he shall have thanks.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1783
verses.text: So do thou.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1784
verses.text: If thine enemy hate thee, and unjustly hate thee; know that the lust of the world reigns in him, therefore he hates thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1785
verses.text: If thou also hate him, thou on the other hand renderest evil for evil.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1786
verses.text: What does it, to render evil for evil? I wept for one sick man who hated thee; now bewail I thee, if thou also hatest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1787
verses.text: But he attacks thy property; he takes from thee I know not what things which thou hast on earth: therefore hatest thou him, because he puts thee to straits on earth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1788
verses.text: Be not thou straitened, remove thee to heaven above; there shalt thou have thine heart where there is wide room, so that thou mayest not be straitened in the hope of life eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1789
verses.text: Consider what the things are that he takes from thee: not even them would he take from thee, but by permission of Him who "scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1790
verses.text: He, this same enemy of thine, is in a manner the instrument in the hands of God, by which thou mayest be healed.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1791
verses.text: If God knows it to be good for thee that he should despoil thee, He permits him; if He knows it to be good for thee that thou shouldest receive blows, He permits him to smite thee: by the means of Him He careth for thee: wish thou that he may be made whole.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1793
verses.text: "No man hath seen God at any time".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1794
verses.text: See, beloved: "If we love one another, God  will dwell in us, and His love will be perfected in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1795
verses.text: Begin to love; thou shalt be perfected.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1796
verses.text: Hast thou begun to love? God has begun to dwell in thee: love Him that has begun to dwell in thee, that by more perfect indwelling He may make thee perfect.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1797
verses.text: "In this we know that we dwell in Him and He in us, because He hath given us of His Spirit".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1798
verses.text: It is well: thanks be to God! We come to know that He dwelleth in us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1799
verses.text: And whence come we to know this very thing, to wit, that we do know that He dwelleth in us? Because John himself has said this: "Because He hath given us of His Spirit".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1800
verses.text: Whence know we that He hath given us of His Spirit? This very thing, that He hath given thee of His Spirit, whence comest thou to know it? Ask thine own bowels: if they are full of charity, thou hast the Spirit of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1801
verses.text: Whence know we that by this thou knowest that the Spirit of God dwelleth in thee? "Because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given unto us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1803
verses.text: "And we have seen, and are witnesses, that God hath sent His Son to be the Saviour of the world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1804
verses.text: Set your minds at rest, ye that are sick: such a Physician is come, and do ye despair? Great were the diseases, incurable were the wounds, desperate was the sickness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1805
verses.text: Dost thou note the greatness of thine ill, and not note the omnipotence of the Physician? Thou art desperate, but He is omnipotent; Whose witnesses are these that first were healed, and that announce the Physician: yet even they are made whole in hope rather than in the reality.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1806
verses.text: For so saith the apostle: "For by hope we are saved".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1807
verses.text: We have begun therefore to be made whole in faith: but our wholeness shall be perfected "when this corruptible shall have put on incorruption, and this mortal shall have put on immortality".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1808
verses.text: This is hope, not the reality.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1809
verses.text: But he that rejoiceth in hope shall hold the reality also: whereas he that hath not the hope, shall not be able to attain unto the reality.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1811
verses.text: "Whosoever shall confess that Jesus is the Son of God, God dwelleth in him and he in God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1812
verses.text: Now we may say it in not many words; "Whosoever shall confess;" not in word but in deed, not with tongue but with the life.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1813
verses.text: For many confess in words, but in deeds deny: "And we have known and believed the love which God hath in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1814
verses.text: And again, by what hast thou come to know this? "Love is God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1815
verses.text: He hath already said it above, behold he saith it again.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1816
verses.text: Love could not be more exceedingly commended to thee than that it should be called God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1817
verses.text: Haply thou wast ready to despise a gift of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1818
verses.text: And dost thou despise God? "Love is God: and he that dwelleth in love dwelleth in God, and God dwelleth in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1819
verses.text: Each mutually inhabiteth the other; He that holdeth, and he that is holden.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1820
verses.text: Thou dwellest in God, but that thou mayest be holden: God inhabiteth thee, but that He may hold thee, lest thou fall.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1821
verses.text: Lest haply thou imagine that thou becomest an house of God in such sort as thine house supports thy flesh: if the house in which thou art withdraw itself from under thee, thou fallest; but if thou withdraw thyself, God falleth not.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1822
verses.text: When thou forsakest Him, He is none the less; when thou hast returned unto Him, He is none the greater.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1823
verses.text: Thou art healed, on Him thou wilt bestow nothing; thou art made clean, thou art new-made, thou art set right: He is a medicine to the unhealthy, is a rule for the crooked, is light for the bedarkened, is an habitation for the deserted.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1824
verses.text: All therefore is conferred on thee: see thou imagine not that ought is conferred upon God by thy coming unto Him: no, not so much as a slave.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1825
verses.text: Shall God, forsooth, not have servants if thou like not, if all like not? God needs not the servants, but the servants need God: therefore saith the Psalm, "I have said unto the Lord, thou art my God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1826
verses.text: He is the true Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1827
verses.text: And what saith it? "For of my goods Thou hast no need".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1828
verses.text: Thou needest the good thou hast by thy servant.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1829
verses.text: Thy servant needeth the good he hath by thee, that thou mayest feed him; thou also needest the good thou hast by thy servant, that he may  help thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1830
verses.text: Thou canst not draw water for thyself, canst not cook for thyself, canst not run before thy horse, canst not tend thy beast.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1831
verses.text: Thou seest that thou needest the good thou hast by thy servant, thou needest his attendance.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1832
verses.text: Therefore thou art not a true lord, while thou hast need of an inferior.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1833
verses.text: He is the true Lord, who seeks nothing from us; and woe to us if we seek not Him! He seeks nothing from us: yet He sought us, when we sought not Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1834
verses.text: One sheep had strayed; He found it, He brought it back on His shoulders rejoicing.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1835
verses.text: And was the sheep necessary for the Shepherd, and not rather the Shepherd necessary for the sheep?â€”The more I love to speak of charity, the less willing am I that this epistle should be finished.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1836
verses.text: None is more ardent in the commending of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1837
verses.text: Nothing more sweet is preached to you, nothing more wholesome drunk by you: but only thus if by godly living ye confirm in you the gift of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1838
verses.text: Be not ungrateful for His so great grace, who, though He had one Only Son, would not that He should be alone a Son; but, that He might have brethren, adopted unto Him those who should with Him possess life eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1839
verses.text: Homily IX.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1840
verses.text: 1 John IV.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1841
verses.text: 17â€“21  "Herein is love made perfect in us, that we may have boldness in the day of judgment: because as He is, so are we in this world.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1842
verses.text: There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear: because fear hath torment.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1843
verses.text: He that feareth is not made perfect in love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1844
verses.text: Let us love Him, because He first loved us.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1845
verses.text: If a man say, I love God, and hateth his brother, he is a liar: for he that loveth not his brother whom he seeth, how can he love God whom he seeth not? And this commandment have we from Him, That he who loveth God love his brother also".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1847
verses.text: Ye remember, beloved, that of the epistles of John the apostle the last past remains to be handled by us and expounded to you, as the Lord vouchsafes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1848
verses.text: Of this debt then we are mindful: and ye ought to be mindful of your claim.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1849
verses.text: For indeed this same charity, which in this epistle is chiefly and almost alone commended, at once maketh us most faithful in paying our debts, and you most sweet in exacting your rights.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1850
verses.text: I have said, most sweet in exacting, because where charity is not, he that exacts is bitter: but where charity is, both he that exacts is sweet, and he of whom it is exacted, although he undertakes some labor, yet charity makes the very labor to be almost no labor, and light.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1851
verses.text: Do we not see how, even in dumb and irrational animals, where the love is not spiritual but carnal and natural, with great affection the mother yields herself to her young ones when they will have the milk which is their right: and however impetuously the suckling rushes at the teats, yet that is better for the mother than that it should not suck nor exact that which of love is due? Often we see great calves driving their heads at the cow's udders with a force that almost lifts up the mother's body, yet does she not kick them off; nay, if the young one be not there to suck, the lowing of the dam calls for it to come to the teats.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1852
verses.text: If then there be in us that spiritual charity of which the apostle saith, "I became small in the midst of you even as a nurse cherishing her young ones;" we love you the more when ye are exacting.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1853
verses.text: We like not the sluggish, because for the languid ones we are afraid.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1854
verses.text: We have been obliged, however, to intermit the continuous reading of this epistle, because of certain stated lessons coming between, which must needs be read on their holy days, and the same preached upon.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1855
verses.text: Let us now come back to the order which was interrupted; and what remains, holy brethren, receive ye with all attention.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1856
verses.text: I know not whether charity could be more magnificently commended to us, than that it should be said, "Charity is God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1857
verses.text: Brief praise, yet mighty praise: brief in utterance, mighty in meaning! How soon is it said, "Love is God!" This also is short: if thou  count it, it is one: if thou weigh it, how great is it! "Love is God, and he that dwelleth," saith he, "in love, dwelleth in God, and God dwelleth in him".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1858
verses.text: Let God be thy house, and be thou an house of God; dwell in God, and let God dwell in thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1859
verses.text: God dwelleth in thee, that He may hold thee: thou dwellest in God, that thou mayest not fall; for thus saith the apostle of this same charity, "Charity never falleth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1860
verses.text: How should He fall whom God holdeth?  2.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1861
verses.text: "Herein is our love made perfect in us that we may have boldness in the day of judgment: because as He is, so are we in this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1862
verses.text: He tells how each may prove himself, what progress charity has made in him or rather what progress he has made in charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1863
verses.text: For if charity is God, God is capable neither of proficiency nor of deficiency: that charity is said to be making proficiency in thee, means only that thou makest proficiency in it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1864
verses.text: Ask therefore what proficiency thou hast made in charity, and what thine heart will answer thee, that thou mayest know the measure of thy profiting.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1865
verses.text: For he has promised to show us in what we may know Him, and hath said, "In this is love made perfect in us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1866
verses.text: Ask, in what? "That we have boldness in the day of judgment".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1867
verses.text: Whoso hath boldness in the day of judgment, in that man is charity made perfect.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1868
verses.text: What is it to have boldness in the day of judgment? Not to fear lest the day of judgment should come.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1869
verses.text: There are men who do not believe in a day of judgment; these cannot have boldness in a day which they do not believe will come.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1870
verses.text: Let us pass these: may God awaken them, that they may live; why speak we of the dead? They do not believe that there will be a day of judgment; they neither fear nor desire what they do not believe.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1871
verses.text: Some man has begun to believe in a day of judgment: if he has begun to believe, he has also begun to fear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1872
verses.text: But because he fears as yet, because he hath not yet boldness in the day of judgment, not yet is charity in that man made perfect.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1873
verses.text: But for all that, is one to despair? In whom thou seest the beginning, why despairest thou of the end? What beginning do I see? (sayest thou.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1874
verses.text: ) That very fear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1875
verses.text: Hear the Scripture: "The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1876
verses.text: Well then, he has begun to fear the day of judgment: by fearing let him correct himself, let him watch against his enemies, i-e: his sins; let him begin to come to life again inwardly, and to mortify his members which are upon the earth, as the apostle saith, "Mortify your members which are upon the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1877
verses.text: By the members upon earth he means spiritual wickedness: for he goes on to expound it, "Covetousness, uncleanness," and the rest which he there follows out.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1878
verses.text: Now in proportion as this man who has begun to fear the day of judgment, mortifies his members which are upon the earth, in that proportion the heavenly members rise up and are strengthened.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1879
verses.text: But the heavenly members are all good works.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1880
verses.text: As the heavenly members rise up, he begins to desire that which once he feared.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1881
verses.text: Once he feared lest Christ should come and find in him the impious whom He must condemn; now he longs for Him to come, because He shall find the pious man whom He may crown.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1882
verses.text: Having now begun to desire Christ's coming, the chaste soul which desires the embrace of the Bridegroom renounces the adulterer, becomes a virgin within by faith, hope, and charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1883
verses.text: Now hath the man boldness in the day of judgment: he fights not against himself when he prays, "Thy kingdom come".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1884
verses.text: For he that fears lest the kingdom of God should come, fears lest his prayer be heard.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1885
verses.text: How can he be said to pray, who fears lest his prayer be heard? But he that prays with boldness of charity, wishes now that He may come.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1886
verses.text: Of this same desire said one in the Psalm, "And thou, Lord, how long? Turn, Lord, and deliver my soul".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1887
verses.text: He groaned at being so put off.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1888
verses.text: For there are men who with patience submit to die; but there are some perfect who with patience endure to live.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1889
verses.text: What do I mean? When a person still desires this life, that person, when the day of death comes, patiently endures death: he struggles against himself that he may follow the will of God, and in his mind desires that which God chooseth, not what man's will chooseth: from desire of the present life there comes a reluctance against death, but yet he takes to him patience and fortitude, that he may with an even mind meet death; he dies patiently.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1890
verses.text: But when a man desires, as the apostle saith, "to be dissolved and to be with Christ," that person, not patiently dies, but patiently lives, delightedly dies.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1891
verses.text: See the apostle patiently living, i-e: how with patience he here, not loves life, but endures it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1892
verses.text: "To be dissolved," saith he, "and to be with Christ, is far better: but to continue in the flesh is necessary for your sakes".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1893
verses.text: Therefore, brethren, do your endeavor, settle it inwardly with yourselves to make this your concern, that ye may desire the day of judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1894
verses.text: No otherwise is charity proved to be  perfect, but only when one has begun to desire that day.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1895
verses.text: But that man desires it, who hath boldness in it, whose conscience feels no alarm in perfect and sincere charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1897
verses.text: "In this is His love perfected in us, that we may have boldness in the day of judgment".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1898
verses.text: Why shall we have boldness? "Because as He is are we also in this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1899
verses.text: Thou hast heard the ground of thy boldness: "Because as He is," saith the apostle, "are we also in this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1900
verses.text: Does he not seem to have said something impossible? For is it possible for man to be as God? I have already expounded to you that "as" is not always said of equality, but is said of a certain resemblance.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1901
verses.text: For how sayest thou, As I have ears, so has my image? Is it quite so? and yet thou sayest "so, as".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1902
verses.text: If then we were made after God's image, why are we not so as God? Not unto equality, but relatively to our measure.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1903
verses.text: Whence then are we given boldness in the day of judgment? "Because as He is, are we also in this world".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1904
verses.text: We must refer this to the same charity, and understand what is meant.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1905
verses.text: The Lord in the Gospel saith, "If ye love them that love you, what reward shall ye have? do not the publicans this?" Then what would He have us do? "But I say unto you, Love your enemies, and pray for them that persecute you".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1906
verses.text: If then He bids us love our enemies, whence brings He an example to set before us? From God Himself: for He saith, "That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1907
verses.text: How doth God this? He loveth His enemies, "Who maketh His sun to rise upon the good and the bad, and raineth upon the just and the unjust".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1908
verses.text: If this then be the perfection unto which God inviteth us, that we love our enemies as He loved His; this is our boldness in the day of judgment, that "as He is, so are we also in this world:" because, as He loveth His enemies in making His sun to rise upon good and bad, and in sending rain upon the just and unjust, so we, since we cannot bestow upon them sun and rain, bestow upon them our tears when we pray for them.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1910
verses.text: Now therefore concerning this same boldness, let us see what he says.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1911
verses.text: Whence do we understand that charity is perfect? "There is no fear in charity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1912
verses.text: Then what say we of him that has begun to fear the day of judgment? If charity in him were perfect, he would not fear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1913
verses.text: For perfect charity would make perfect righteousness, and he would have nothing to fear: nay rather he would have something to desire; that iniquity may pass away, and God's kingdom come.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1914
verses.text: So then, "there is no fear in charity".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1915
verses.text: But in what charity? Not in charity begun: in what then? "But perfect charity," saith he, "casteth out fear".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1916
verses.text: Then let fear make the beginning, because "the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1917
verses.text: Fear, so to say, prepares a place for charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1918
verses.text: But when once charity has begun to inhabit, the fear which prepared the place for it is cast out.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1919
verses.text: For in proportion as this increases, that decreases: and the more this comes to be within, is the fear cast out.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1920
verses.text: Greater charity, less fear; less charity, greater fear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1921
verses.text: But if no fear, there is no way for charity to come in.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1922
verses.text: As we see in sewing, the thread is introduced by means of the bristle; the bristle first enters, but except it come out the thread does not come into its place: so fear first occupies the mind, but the fear does not remain there, because it enters only in order to introduce charity.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1923
verses.text: When once there is the sense of security in the mind, what joy have we both in this world and in the world to come! Even in this world, who shall hurt us, being full of charity? See how the apostle exults concerning this very charity: "Who shall separate us from the charity of Christ? shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?" And Peter saith: "And who is he that will harm you, if ye be followers of that which is good?â€”There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear: because fear hath torment".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1924
verses.text: The consciousness of sins torments the heart: justification has not yet taken place.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1925
verses.text: There is that in it which itches, which pricks.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1926
verses.text: Accordingly in the Psalm what saith he concerning this same perfection of righteousness? "Thou hast turned for me my mourning into joy: Thou hast put off my sackcloth, and girded me with gladness; to the end that my glory may sing to thee, and that I be not pricked".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1927
verses.text: What is this, "That I be not pricked?" That there be not that which shall goad my conscience.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1928
verses.text: Fear doth goad: but fear not thou: charity enters in, and she heals the wound that fear inflicts.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1929
verses.text: The fear of God so wounds as doth the leech's knife; it takes away the rottenness, and seems to make the wound greater.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1930
verses.text: Behold, when the rottenness was in the body, the wound was less, but perilous: then comes the knife; the wound smarted less than it smarts now while the leech is cutting it.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1931
verses.text: It smarts more while he is operating upon it than it would if it were  not operated upon; it smarts more under the healing operation, but only that it may never smart when the healing is effected.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1932
verses.text: Then let fear occupy thine heart, that it may bring in charity; let the cicatrice succeed to the leech's knife.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1933
verses.text: He is such an Healer, that the cicatrices do not even appear: only do thou put thyself under His hand.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1934
verses.text: For if thou be without fear, thou canst not be justified.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1935
verses.text: It is a sentence pronounced by the Scriptures; "For he that is without fear, cannot be justified".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1936
verses.text: Needs then must fear first enter in, that by it charity may come.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1937
verses.text: Fear is the healing operation: charity, the sound condition.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1938
verses.text: "But he that feareth is not made perfect in love".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1939
verses.text: Why? "Because fear hath torment;" just as the cutting of the surgeon's knife hath torment.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1941
verses.text: But there is another sentence, which seems contrary to this if it have not one that understands.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1942
verses.text: Namely, it is said in a certain place of the Psalms, "The fear of the Lord is chaste, enduring forever".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1943
verses.text: He shows us an eternal fear, but a chaste.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1944
verses.text: But if he there shows us an eternal fear, does this epistle perchance contradict him, when it saith, "There is no fear in love, but perfect love casteth out fear?" Let us interrogate both utterances of God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1945
verses.text: One is the Spirit, though the books two, though the mouths two, though the tongues two.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1946
verses.text: For this is said by the mouth of John, that by the mouth of David: but think not that the Spirit is more than one.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1947
verses.text: If one breath fills two pipes [of the double-flute], cannot one Spirit fill two hearts, move two tongues? But if two pipes filled by one breathing sound in unison, can two tongues filled with the Spirit or Breathing of God make a dissonance? There is then an unison there, there is a harmony, only it requires one that can hear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1948
verses.text: Behold, this Spirit of God hath breathed into and filled two hearts, hath moved two tongues: and we have heard from the one tongue, "There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear;" we have heard from the other, "The fear of the Lord is chaste, enduring for ever".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1949
verses.text: How is this? The notes seem to jar.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1950
verses.text: Not so: rouse thine ears: mark the melody.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1951
verses.text: It is not without cause that in the one place there is added that word, chaste, in the other it is not added: but because there is one fear which is called chaste, and there is another fear which is not called chaste.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1952
verses.text: Let us mark the difference between these two fears, and so understand the harmony of the flutes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1953
verses.text: How are we to understand, or how to distinguish? Mark, my beloved.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1954
verses.text: There are men who fear God, lest they be cast into hell, lest haply they burn with the devil in everlasting fire.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1955
verses.text: This is the fear which introduces charity: but it comes that it may depart.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1956
verses.text: For if thou as yet fearest God because of punishments, not yet dost thou love Him whom thou in such sort fearest.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1957
verses.text: Thou dost not desire the good things, but art afraid of the evil things.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1958
verses.text: Yet because thou art afraid of the evil things, thou correctest thyself and beginnest to desire the good things.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1959
verses.text: When once thou hast begun to desire the good, there shall be in thee the chaste fear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1960
verses.text: What is the chaste fear? The fear lest thou lose the good things themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1961
verses.text: Mark! It is one thing to fear God lest He cast thee into hell with the devil, and another thing to fear God lest He forsake thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1962
verses.text: The fear by which thou fearest lest thou be cast into hell with the devil, is not yet chaste; for it comes not from the love of God, but from the fear of punishment: but when thou fearest God lest His presence forsake thee, thou embracest Him, thou longest to enjoy God Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1964
verses.text: One cannot better explain the difference between these two fears, the one which charity casteth out, the other chaste, which endureth for ever, than by putting the case of two married women, one of whom, you may suppose, is willing to commit adultery, delights in wickedness, only fears lest she be condemned by her husband.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1965
verses.text: She fears her husband: but because she yet loves wickedness, that is the reason why she fears her husband.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1966
verses.text: To this woman, the presence of her husband is not grateful but burdensome; and if it chance she live wickedly, she fears her husband, lest he should come.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1967
verses.text: Such are they that fear the coming of the day of judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1968
verses.text: Put the case that the other loves her husband, that she feels that she owes him chaste embraces, that she stains herself with no uncleanness of adultery; she wishes for the presence of her husband.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1969
verses.text: And how are these two fears distinguished? The one woman fears, the other also fears.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1970
verses.text: Question them: they seem to make one answer: question the one, Dost thou fear thine husband? she answers, I do.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1971
verses.text: Question the other, whether she fears her husband; she answers, I do fear him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1972
verses.text: The voice is one, the mind diverse.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1973
verses.text: Now then let them be questioned, Why? The one saith, I fear my husband, lest he should come: the other saith, I fear my husband, lest he depart from me.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1974
verses.text: The one saith, I fear to be condemned: the other, I fear to be forsaken.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1975
verses.text: Let the like have place in the mind of Christians, and thou findest a fear which love casteth out, and another fear, chaste, enduring for ever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1977
verses.text: Let us speak then first to these who fear God, just in the manner of that woman who delights in wickedness; namely, she fears her husband lest he condemn her; to such let us first speak.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1978
verses.text: O soul, which fearest God lest He condemn thee, just as the woman fears, who delights in wickedness: fears her husband, lest she be condemned by her husband: as thou art displeased at this woman, so be displeased at thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1979
verses.text: If perchance thou hast a wife, wouldest thou have thy wife fear thee thus, that she be not condemned by thee? that delighting in wickedness, she should be repressed only by the weight of the fear of thee, not by the condemnation of her iniquity? Thou wouldest have her chaste, that she may love thee, not that she may fear thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1980
verses.text: Show thyself such to God, as thou wouldest have thy wife be to thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1981
verses.text: And if thou hast not yet a wife, and wishest to have one, thou wouldest have her such.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1982
verses.text: And yet what are we saying, brethren? That woman, whose fear of her husband is to be condemned by her husband, perhaps does not commit adultery, lest by some means or other it come to her husband's knowledge, and he deprive her of this temporal light of life: now the husband can be deceived and kept in ignorance; for he is but human, as she is who can deceive him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1983
verses.text: She fears him, from whose eyes she can be hid: and dost thou not fear the face ever upon thee of thine Husband? "The countenance of the Lord is against them that do evil".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1984
verses.text: She catches at her husband's absence, and haply is incited by the delight of adultery; and yet she saith to herself, I will not do it: he indeed is absent, but it is hard to keep it from coming in some way to his knowledge.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1985
verses.text: She restrains herself, lest it come to the knowledge of a mortal man, one who, it is also possible, may never know it, who, it is also possible, may be deceived, so that he shall esteem a bad woman to be good, esteem her to be chaste who is an adulteress: and dost thou not fear the eyes of Him whom no man can deceive? thou not fear the presence of Him who cannot be turned away from thee? Pray God to look upon thee, and to turn His face away from thy sins; "Turn away Thy face from my sins".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1986
verses.text: But whereby dost thou merit that He should turn away His face from thy sins, if thou turn not away thine own face from thy sins? For the same voice saith in the Psalm: "For I acknowledge mine iniquity, and my sin is ever before me".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1987
verses.text: Acknowledge thou, and He forgives.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1989
verses.text: We have addressed that soul which hath as yet the fear which endureth not for ever, but which love shuts out and casts forth: let us address that also which hath now the fear which is chaste, enduring for ever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1990
verses.text: Shall we find that soul, think you, that we may address it? think you, is it here in this congregation? is it, think you, here in this chancel? think you, is it here on earth? It cannot but be, only it is hidden.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1991
verses.text: Now is the winter: within is the greenness in the root.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1992
verses.text: Haply we may get at the ears of that soul.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1993
verses.text: But wherever that soul is, oh that I could find it, and instead of its giving ear to me, might myself give ear to it! It should teach me something, rather than learn of me! An holy soul, a soul of fire, and longing for the kingdom of God: that soul, not I address, but God Himself doth address, and thus consoleth while patiently it endures to live here on earth: "Thou wouldest that I should even now come, and I know that thou wishest I should even now come: I know what thou art, such that without fear thou mayest wait for mine advent; I know that is a trouble to thee: but do thou even longer wait, endure; I come, and come quickly".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1994
verses.text: But to the loving soul the time moves slowly.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1995
verses.text: Hear her singing, like a lily as she is from amid the thorns; hear her sighing and saying, "I will sing, and will understand in a faultless way: when will thou come unto me?" But in a faultless way well may she not fear; because "perfect love casteth out fear".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1996
verses.text: And when He is come to her embrace, still she fears, but in the manner of one that feels secure.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1997
verses.text: What does she fear? She will beware and take heed to herself against her own iniquity, that she sin not again: not lest she be cast into the fire, but lest she be forsaken by Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1998
verses.text: And there shall be in in herâ€”what? the "chaste fear, enduring for ever".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:1999
verses.text: We have heard the two flutes sounding in unison.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2000
verses.text: That speaks of fear, and this speaks of fear: but that, of the fear with which the soul fears lest she be condemned; this, of the fear with which the soul fears lest she be forsaken.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2001
verses.text: That is the fear which charity casteth out: this, the fear that endureth for ever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2003
verses.text: "Let us love, because He first loved us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2004
verses.text: For how should we love, except He had first loved us? By loving we became  friends: but He loved us as enemies, that we might be made friends.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2005
verses.text: He first loved us, and gave us the gift of loving Him.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2006
verses.text: We did not yet love Him: by loving we are made beautiful.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2007
verses.text: If a man deformed and ill-featured love a beautiful woman, what shall he do? Or what shall a woman do, if, being deformed and ill-featured and black-complexioned, she love a beautiful man? By loving can she become beautiful? Can he by loving become handsome? He loves a beautiful woman, and when he sees himself in a mirror, he is ashamed to lift up his face to her his lovely one of whom he is enamored.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2008
verses.text: What shall he do that he may be beautiful? Does he wait for good looks to come? Nay rather, by waiting old age is added to him, and makes him uglier.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2009
verses.text: There is nothing then to do, there is no way to advise him, but only that he should restrain himself, and not presume to love unequally: or if perchance he does love her, and wishes to take her to wife, in her let him love chastity, not the face of flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2010
verses.text: But our soul, my brethren, is unlovely by reason of iniquity: by loving God it becomes lovely.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2011
verses.text: What a love must that be that makes the lover beautiful! But God is always lovely, never unlovely, never changeable.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2012
verses.text: Who is always lovely first loved us; and what were we when He loved us but foul and unlovely? But not to leave us foul; no, but to change us, and of unlovely make us lovely.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2013
verses.text: How shall we become lovely? By loving Him who is always lovely.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2014
verses.text: As the love increases in thee, so the loveliness increases: for love is itself the beauty of the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2015
verses.text: "Let us love, because He first loved us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2016
verses.text: Hear the apostle Paul: "But God showed His love in us, in that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us:" the just for the unjust, the beautiful for the foul.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2017
verses.text: How find we Jesus beautiful? "Thou art beauteous in loveliness surpassing the sons of men; grace is poured upon thy lips".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2018
verses.text: Why so? Again see why it is that He is fair; "Beauteous in loveliness surpassing the sons of men:" because "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2019
verses.text: But in that He took flesh, He took upon Him, as it were, thy foulness, i-e: thy mortality, that He might adapt Himself to thee, and become suited to thee, and stir thee up to the love of the beauteousness within.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2020
verses.text: Where then in Scripture do we find Jesus uncomely and deformed, as we have found Him comely and "beauteous in loveliness surpassing the sons of men?" where find we Him also deformed? Ask Esaias: "And we saw Him, and He had no form nor comeliness".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2021
verses.text: There now are two flutes which seem to make discordant sounds: howbeit one Spirit breathes into both.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2022
verses.text: By this it is said, "Beauteous in loveliness surpassing the sons of men:" by that it is said in Esaias, "We saw Him, and He had no form nor comeliness".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2023
verses.text: By one Spirit are both flutes filled, they make no dissonance.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2024
verses.text: Turn not away thine ears, apply the understanding.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2025
verses.text: Let us ask the apostle Paul, and let him expound to us the unison of the two flutes.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2026
verses.text: Let him sound to us the note, "Beauteous in loveliness surpassing the sons of men.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2027
verses.text: â€”Who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2028
verses.text: Let him sound to us also the note, "We saw Him, and He had no form nor comeliness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2029
verses.text: â€”He made Himself of no reputation, taking upon Him the form of a servant, made in the likeness of men, and in fashion found as man.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2030
verses.text: He had no form nor comeliness," that He might give thee form and comeliness.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2031
verses.text: What form? what comeliness? The love which is in charity: that loving, thou mayest run; running, mayest love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2032
verses.text: Thou art fair now: but stay not thy regard upon thyself, lest thou lose what thou hast received; let thy regards terminate in Him by whom thou wast made fair.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2033
verses.text: Be thou fair only to the end He may love thee.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2034
verses.text: But do thou direct thy whole aim to Him, run thou to Him, seek His embraces, fear to depart from Him; that there may be in thee the chaste fear, which endureth for ever.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2035
verses.text: "Let us love, because He first loved us".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2037
verses.text: "If any man say, I love God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2038
verses.text: What God? wherefore love we? "Because He first loved us," and gave us to love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2039
verses.text: He loved us ungodly, to make us godly; loved us unrighteous, to make us righteous; loved us sick, to make us whole.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2040
verses.text: Ask each several man; let him tell thee if he love God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2041
verses.text: He cries out, he confesses: I love, God knoweth.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2042
verses.text: There is another question to be asked.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2043
verses.text: "If any man say, I love God, and hateth his brother, he is a liar".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2044
verses.text: By what provest thou that he is a liar? Hear.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2045
verses.text: "For he that loveth not his brother whom he seeth, how can he love God whom he seeth not?" What then? does he that loves a brother, love God also? He must of necessity love God, must of necessity love Him that is Love itself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2046
verses.text: Can one love his brother, and not love Love? Of necessity he must love Love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2047
verses.text: What then? because he loves Love, does it follow that he loves God? Certainly it does follow.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2048
verses.text: In  loving Love, he loves God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2049
verses.text: Or hast thou forgotten what thou saidst a little while ago, "Love is God"? If "Love is God," whoso loveth Love, loveth God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2050
verses.text: Love then thy brother, and feel thyself assured.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2051
verses.text: Thou canst not say, "I love my brother, but I do not love God".

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2052
verses.text: As thou liest, if thou sayest "I love God," when thou lovest not thy brother, so thou art deceived when thou sayest, I love my brother, if thou think that thou lovest not God.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2053
verses.text: Of necessity must thou who lovest thy brother, love Love itself: but "Love is God:" therefore of necessity must he love God, whoso loveth his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2054
verses.text: But if thou love not the brother whom thou seest, how canst thou love God whom thou seest not? Why does he not see God? Because he has not Love itself.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2055
verses.text: That he does not see God, is, because he has not love: that he has not love, is, because he loves not his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2056
verses.text: The reason then why he does not see God, is, that he has not Love.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2057
verses.text: For if he have Love, he sees God, for "Love is God:" and that eye is becoming more and more purged by love, to see that Unchangeable Substance, in the presence of which he shall always rejoice, which he shall enjoy to everlasting, when he is joined with the angels.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2058
verses.text: Only, let him run now, that he may at last have gladness in his own country.

verses.name: Augustine: First Epistle of John 2:2059
